	<div class="site grid-container container hfeed grid-parent" id="page">
				<div class="site-content" id="content">
			
	<div class="content-area grid-parent mobile-grid-100 grid-70 tablet-grid-70" id="primary">
		<main class="site-main" id="main">
			
<article id="post-27857" class="post-27857 page type-page status-publish mv-content-wrapper" itemtype="https://schema.org/CreativeWork" itemscope>
	<div class="inside-article">
		
			<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">How to Do Band-Assisted Bench Press: Muscles Worked &amp; Proper Form</h1>			</header>

			
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="text">
			<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/bench-with-band-assistance.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="How to do band assisted bench press with proper form" class="wp-image-27842" data-recalc-dims="1"/></figure></div>


<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-1 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-muscles-worked-in-band-assisted-bench-press">Muscles Worked in Band-Assisted Bench Press</h2>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-floor-press-exercise-1024x1024.png?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscles worked in the Band-Assisted Bench Press exercise" class="wp-image-4343" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-floor-press-exercise.png?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-floor-press-exercise.png?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-floor-press-exercise.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-floor-press-exercise.png?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-floor-press-exercise.png?w=1125&amp;ssl=1 1125w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-primary-muscles-worked">Primary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-muscles-exercises-workout/">Chest</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/front-delts-muscle-exercises-workout/">Front Deltoid</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-secondary-muscles-worked">Secondary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/triceps-muscles-exercises-workout/">Triceps</a></li>
</ul>
</div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-do-band-assisted-bench-press">How to Do Band-Assisted Bench Press</h2>



<ol>
<li>Attach the resistance band under the bench, loop it around the barbell, and back under the bench.</li>



<li>Lie on the bench with feet flat, back slightly arched, and shoulder blades retracted.</li>



<li>Grip the barbell at your preferred width.</li>



<li>Unrack the barbell and position it above your chest.</li>



<li>Lower the barbell to your chest, keeping tension in your upper body.</li>



<li>Press the barbell back up to the starting position against the band.</li>



<li>Repeat for reps.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-commentary">Commentary</h2>



<p>The bench press against bands is a variation of the bench press in which resistance bands increase the tension as you press up. This makes it more challenging to lock out the lift, enhancing strength and power. It&#8217;s typically used to improve explosive strength and stability. Make sure to use the safety racks or to have a spotter while performing this exercise.</p>
</div>
</div>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/exercise-directory/">&gt;&gt; Return to exercise directory.</a></p>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity"/>



<p><em>Text and graphics from the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">StrengthLog </a>app.</em></p>
		</div>

			</div>
</article>
		</main>
	</div>

	<div class="site grid-container container hfeed grid-parent" id="page">
				<div class="site-content" id="content">
			
	<div class="content-area grid-parent mobile-grid-100 grid-70 tablet-grid-70" id="primary">
		<main class="site-main" id="main">
			
<article id="post-2631" class="post-2631 page type-page status-publish mv-content-wrapper" itemtype="https://schema.org/CreativeWork" itemscope>
	<div class="inside-article">
		
			<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">How to Do Cable Chest Press: Muscles Worked &#038; Proper Form</h1>			</header>

			
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="text">
			<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/cable-chest-press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Cable Chest Press exercise technique" class="wp-image-2632" data-recalc-dims="1"/></figure></div>


<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-1 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-muscles-worked-in-cable-chest-press">Muscles Worked in Cable Chest Press</h2>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-cable-chest-press.png?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscles worked by cable chest press" class="wp-image-4365" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-cable-chest-press.png?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-cable-chest-press.png?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-cable-chest-press.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-cable-chest-press.png?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Muscles-worked-by-cable-chest-press.png?w=1125&amp;ssl=1 1125w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-primary-muscles-worked">Primary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-muscles-exercises-workout/">Chest</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-secondary-muscles-worked">Secondary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/front-delts-muscle-exercises-workout/">Front Deltoid</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/triceps-muscles-exercises-workout/">Triceps</a></li>
</ul>
</div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-do-cable-chest-press">How to Do Cable Chest Press</h2>



<ol>
<li>Fasten a pair of handles in the top position of a cable cross. Grip the handles, step forward, and lean slightly forward.</li>



<li>Push the handles forward until they meet in front of your body.</li>



<li>With control, let the handles go back to the starting position.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-commentary">Commentary</h2>



<p>Cable chest press is a pressing exercise with a different resistance curve than for example <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/dumbbell-chest-press/">dumbbell chest press</a>, as the direction of resistance comes more from the sides. That might make it easier to keep tension on the chest muscles throughout the whole movement, and thus possibly benefit muscle growth.</p>
</div>
</div>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/exercise-directory/">&gt;&gt; Return to exercise directory.</a></p>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity"/>



<p><em>Text and graphics from the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">StrengthLog </a>app.</em></p>
		</div>

			</div>
</article>
		</main>
	</div>

<article id="post-2084" class="post-2084 page type-page status-publish mv-content-wrapper" itemtype="https://schema.org/CreativeWork" itemscope>
	<div class="inside-article">
		
			<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">How to Bench Press: Muscles Worked &#038; Proper Form</h1>			</header>

			
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="text">
			<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/bench-press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Bench Press Exercise" class="wp-image-10664" data-recalc-dims="1"/></figure></div>


<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-1 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-muscles-worked-in-the-bench-press">Muscles Worked in the Bench Press</h2>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" width="563" height="563" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Muscles-worked-in-the-bench-press-exercise-2.jpg?resize=563%2C563&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscles worked in the bench press exercise" class="wp-image-28320" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Muscles-worked-in-the-bench-press-exercise-2.jpg?w=563&amp;ssl=1 563w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Muscles-worked-in-the-bench-press-exercise-2.jpg?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Muscles-worked-in-the-bench-press-exercise-2.jpg?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w" sizes="(max-width: 563px) 100vw, 563px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-primary-muscles-worked">Primary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-muscles-exercises-workout/">Chest</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/front-delts-muscle-exercises-workout/">Front Deltoid</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-secondary-muscles-worked">Secondary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/triceps-muscles-exercises-workout/">Triceps</a></li>
</ul>
</div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-bench-press-with-proper-form">How to Bench Press with Proper Form</h2>



<ol>
<li>Lie on the bench, pull your shoulder blades together and down, and slightly arch your back.</li>



<li>Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.</li>



<li>Inhale, hold your breath, and unrack the bar.</li>



<li>Lower the bar with control, until it touches your chest somewhere close to your sternum.</li>



<li>Push the bar up to the starting position while exhaling.</li>



<li>Take another breath while in the top position, and repeat for reps.</li>
</ol>



<p><em>Text and graphics from the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">StrengthLog&nbsp;</a>app.</em></p>
</div>
</div>



<p>The barbell bench press is one of the most popular exercises in the world and one of the best <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-exercises/">chest exercises</a> you can do.</p>



<p>On this page, you&#8217;ll learn about bench press strength standards, how to get stronger in the bench press, and how to perform the bench press with a strong, safe technique.</p>



<div id="ez-toc-container" class="ez-toc-v2_0_67_1 counter-hierarchy ez-toc-counter ez-toc-grey ez-toc-container-direction">
<p class="ez-toc-title">Table of Contents</p>
<label for="ez-toc-cssicon-toggle-item-66802823c1b57" class="ez-toc-cssicon-toggle-label"><span class=""><span class="eztoc-hide" style="display:none;">Toggle</span><span Max</a></li><li class='ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2'><a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-4" href="#Bench_Press_Form_Detailed_Instructions" title="Bench Press Form: Detailed FAQ</a></li></ul></nav></div>
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="bench-press-1rm-calculator"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Bench_Press_1RM_Calculator"></span>Bench Press 1RM Calculator<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Use our bench press calculator to estimate how much you can lift in a one-rep max.</p>



<p>Enter the number of&nbsp;<strong>reps&nbsp;</strong>you can do with a given&nbsp;<strong>weight</strong>&nbsp;and hit enter, and we will calculate your one-rep max and your 1–10RM.</p>


<noscript><link rel='stylesheet' id='formidable-css' href='https://149874912.v2.pressablecdn.com/wp-content/plugins/formidable/css/formidableforms.css?ver=6191902' media='all' />

<p>The results are calculated using Epley’s equation. It is one of the most accurate formulas for calculating <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM</a> in the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squat</a>,&nbsp;bench press, and&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/deadlift/">deadlift</a>.<span id='easy-footnote-1-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-1-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Abstract/1997/11000/The_Accuracy_of_Prediction_Equations_for.1.aspx&quot;&gt;The Accuracy of Prediction Equations for Estimating 1-RM Performance in the Bench Press, Squat, and Deadlift, Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research: November 1997 – Volume 11 – Issue 4 – p 211-213.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>1</sup></a></span>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="bench-press-strength-standards"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Bench_Press_Strength_Standards"></span>Bench Press Strength Standards<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>How much can the average man and woman bench press?</p>



<figure class="wp-block-table is-style-stripes"><table><thead><tr><th>Strength Level</th><th>Men</th><th>Women</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Beginner</td><td>54 kg (119 lb)</td><td>25 kg (55 lb)</td></tr><tr><td>Novice</td><td>80 kg (176 lb)</td><td>37 kg (82 lb)</td></tr><tr><td>Intermediate</td><td>100 kg (220 lb)</td><td>47 kg (104 lb)</td></tr><tr><td>Advanced</td><td>120 kg (265 lb)</td><td>58 kg (128 lb)</td></tr><tr><td>Elite</td><td>168 kg (370 lb)</td><td>90 kg (198 lb)</td></tr></tbody></table></figure>



<p>These are average bench press standards based on the users of our workout tracker <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">StrengthLog</a>.</p>



<p>Click below to see our complete bench press standards at different bodyweights:</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-strength-standards-kg/">Bench Press Standards in Kilograms</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-strength-standards-lb/">Bench Press Standards in Pounds</a></li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="how-to-increase-your-bench-press-1rm"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="How_to_Increase_Your_Bench_Press_Max"></span>How to Increase Your Bench Press Max<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>We have several training programs for increasing your bench press.</p>



<p>Here are three programs for different training levels:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/beginner-bench-press-program/">Beginner Bench Press Program</a>. 2x/week.&nbsp;</strong>A super simple yet effective beginner bench press program that will give you quick gains and a great start to your bench press career.</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/intermediate-bench-press-program/">Intermediate Bench Press Program</a>. 2–3x/week.</strong>&nbsp;A bench press program for the intermediate lifter who has left the beginner phase behind, but is not yet ready for advanced bench press training.</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/advanced-bench-press-program/">Advanced Bench Press Program</a>. 3 x/week.</strong>&nbsp;A bench press program for the advanced lifter, who needs to do a lot of training in order to progress. Nine weeks long, and ends in a short peaking phase and a max attempt.</li>
</ul>



<p>You can view all our <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-programs/">bench press programs here</a>.</p>



<p>Also, see our guide on <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-to-increase-bench-press/">how to increase your bench press</a>.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-know-if-you-are-a-beginner-intermediate-or-advanced-bench-presser">How To Know if You Are a Beginner, Intermediate, or Advanced Bench Presser</h3>



<p>There are many ways to classify experience level, but I like the clarity of these definitions from&nbsp;<em>Practical Programming</em>:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Beginner:&nbsp;</strong>Gets significantly stronger from workout to workout.</li>



<li><strong>Intermediate:&nbsp;</strong>Gets significantly stronger from week to week, or bi-weekly.</li>



<li><strong>Advanced:&nbsp;</strong>Gets significantly stronger from month to month, or longer.</li>
</ul>



<p>By “significantly stronger”, I mean that you can add 2.5 kg (or 5 lb) and do the same number of reps, or use the same weight but do more reps.</p>



<p>For example: If you could lift 100 kg for five reps last week, and can lift 102.5 kg for five reps this week, then you’ve gotten significantly stronger.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-increase-your-bench-press-at-the-beginner-level">How to Increase Your Bench Press at the Beginner Level</h3>



<p>Increasing your bench press at the beginner level all comes down to <strong>practice.</strong> You should focus on learning the movement correctly and building your confidence in lifting heavy weights.</p>



<p>You accomplish this by:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Practicing the bench press regularly.</strong>&nbsp;About twice a week is a good mark for quick gains in strength and technique, while still keeping the risk of overuse injury low.</li>



<li><strong>Starting light.&nbsp;</strong>I know you’re eager, but things will get heavy really fast. Temper yourself for the first few weeks of light training, and you will have a <strong>much </strong>easier time getting the technique right.</li>



<li><strong>Progressing.&nbsp;</strong>Here’s the fun part. Every workout, you will take a step forward in either weights or&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-many-reps-should-you-do-to-build-muscle-vs-strength/">reps</a>.</li>
</ul>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/beginner-bench-press-program/">&gt;&gt; Beginner Bench Press Program, 2 Days/Week</a></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">How to Increase Your Bench Press at the Intermediate Level </h3>



<p>When you’re a beginner, getting stronger is&nbsp;<em>easy</em>.</p>



<p>The law of diminishing returns dictates that your gains will come the fastest and easiest in the beginning, and the more advanced you get, the more you will have to work for every extra plate on the bar.</p>



<p>This pattern is the same for any sport. And just like athletes in other sports, you need to make the same adjustments as you get more advanced, according to the fundamental principles of training.</p>



<p>Generally, all of the following three increases:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>The necessary training volume.</strong>&nbsp;The more accustomed you become to your training, the higher the threshold you must overcome to stimulate continued gains.</li>



<li><strong>The need for specialization.</strong>&nbsp;The higher the degree of performance you want in your given sport or lift, the more you need to specialize your training for that goal.</li>



<li><strong>The need for individualization.</strong>&nbsp;A&nbsp;beginner program&nbsp;will work for everyone, more or less. As you increase your&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/training-volume/">training volume</a>&nbsp;and degree of specialization, it will become increasingly important to fit the training to your capabilities and needs. One lifter might thrive on bench pressing four times per week, while another will just hurt their elbows. Some will thrive on a high volume program while others gain better on something more moderate. You will have to try different training programs to find what suits you.</li>
</ul>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/intermediate-bench-press-program/">&gt;&gt; Intermediate Bench Press Program, 2–3 Days/Week</a></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">How to Increase Your Bench Press at the Advanced Level</h3>



<p>When you were a beginner, you could slap on an additional, small weight plate on the barbell pretty much every workout. Every workout was “heavy” in the sense that you were always progressing and taking one step forward.</p>



<p>When you entered the intermediate stage, you could no longer progress every workout. You started to utilize some manner of periodization, like the wave progression&nbsp;<em>heavy–light–medium</em>&nbsp;that we use in our intermediate bench program.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter"><img decoding="async" width="2193" height="1467" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?resize=825%2C552&amp;ssl=1" alt="Wave progression" class="wp-image-12616" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?w=2193&amp;ssl=1 2193w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?resize=300%2C201&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?resize=1024%2C685&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?resize=768%2C514&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?resize=1536%2C1028&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?resize=2048%2C1370&amp;ssl=1 2048w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/Wave-progression.png?w=2100&amp;ssl=1 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /></figure></div>


<p>At the advanced stage, this model still applies but on a larger scale: You still have heavy, light, and medium workouts. But now, you also start having heavy, light, and medium&nbsp;<em>weeks</em>.</p>



<p>Besides this, all the principles mentioned for getting stronger in the intermediate stage still apply. You will need to increase your:</p>



<ul>
<li>Training volume</li>



<li>Specialization</li>



<li>Individualization</li>
</ul>



<p>And you need to do this in a structured manner to avoid injuries or burning out, but still train hard enough to make progress.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/advanced-bench-press-program/">&gt;&gt; Advanced Bench Press Program, 3 Days/Week</a></p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="bench-press-form-detailed-instructions"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Bench_Press_Form_Detailed_Instructions"></span>Bench Press Form: Detailed Instructions<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Let&#8217;s get into the nitty-gritty details of how to properly perform the barbell bench press.</p>



<p>Here&#8217;s what we&#8217;ll cover:</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="#h-position-on-the-bench">Position on the bench</a></li>



<li><a href="#h-grip-width">Grip Width</a></li>



<li><a href="#h-hand-position">Hand Position</a></li>



<li><a href="#elbow-position">Elbows</a></li>



<li><a href="#shoulder-blades">Shoulder blades</a></li>



<li><a href="#foot-position">Feet</a></li>



<li><a href="#leg-drive">Leg drive</a></li>



<li><a href="#bench-press-arch">Arch</a></li>



<li><a href="#pause-or-touch-and-go">Pause or touch and go</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-position-on-the-bench">Position on the Bench</h3>



<p>In most bench press federations, the back of your head, your upper back, and your glutes must remain in contact with the bench at all times, and your feet must touch the floor.</p>



<p>You should place yourself close enough to the bar so that you can easily unrack it.</p>



<ul>
<li><span style="font-size: inherit;">If you are too close to the foot end of the bench, unracking the bar will be excessively heavy.</span></li>



<li>If you are too close to the head end, you will hit the rack with the bar when you&#8217;re lifting.</li>
</ul>



<p>A good rule of thumb is to lie down so that your eyes or nose are directly below the racked bar. This will be close enough for you to unrack it easily, but not close enough to hit the rack while you&#8217;re benching.</p>



<p>If you&#8217;re tall, you can probably slide even closer to the head end without hitting the rack, and if you&#8217;re short, you might have to be a little bit closer to the foot end.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="530" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-setup-position.jpg?resize=700%2C530&#038;ssl=1" alt="Bench press setup" class="wp-image-13436" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-setup-position.jpg?resize=1024%2C776&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-setup-position.jpg?resize=300%2C227&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-setup-position.jpg?resize=768%2C582&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-setup-position.jpg?w=1441&amp;ssl=1 1441w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">I&#8217;m fairly tall and can lie down so that the bar is racked roughly over my mouth, without slamming into the rack when I lift.</figcaption></figure></div>

<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="568" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-starting-position.jpg?resize=700%2C568&#038;ssl=1" alt="Bench press starting position" class="wp-image-13438" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-starting-position.jpg?resize=1024%2C831&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-starting-position.jpg?resize=300%2C244&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-starting-position.jpg?resize=768%2C624&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-starting-position.jpg?w=1441&amp;ssl=1 1441w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Unracked.</figcaption></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-wide-should-you-grip-the-bar">How Wide Should You Grip the Bar?</h3>



<p>Your correct grip width will depend on your anatomy, and also your goal with the exercise. Typically, people are stronger (can lift more weight) with a wider grip than with a narrower grip.</p>



<ul>
<li>Twelve bench press athletes competing at national and international levels were found to be 5–10% stronger with a wide grip of 81 cm (about 2x shoulder-width) compared to narrow (1x shoulder-width) or medium (1.5x shoulder-width) grip.<span id='easy-footnote-2-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-2-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5504579/&quot;&gt;J Hum Kinet. 2017 Jun; 57: 61–71. The Effects of Bench Press Variations in Competitive Athletes on Muscle Activity and Performance.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>2</sup></a></span></li>



<li>Fourteen recreationally trained men performed bench press <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>testing with a close, medium, and wide grip width. They lifted 5–6% more weight in the medium and wide grip compared to the narrow grip, but there wasn&#8217;t any difference between the medium and wide grip (108.9 vs. 109.8 kg).<span id='easy-footnote-3-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-3-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7862765/&quot;&gt;Front Sports Act Living. 2020; 2: 637066. A Biomechanical Analysis of Wide, Medium, and Narrow Grip Width Effects on Kinematics, Horizontal Kinetics, and Muscle Activity on the Sticking Region in Recreationally Trained Males During 1-RM Bench Pressing.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>3</sup></a></span></li>
</ul>



<p>The wider you grip the bar, the greater is the contribution of your chest and front delts. Conversely, the narrower you grip the bar, the greater is the contribution of your triceps.</p>



<ul>
<li>In a wide-grip&nbsp;bench press, your chest and front delts contribute 78% of the force necessary to lift the bar, while your triceps contribute 22%.</li>



<li>In a <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-bench-press/">close-grip bench press</a>, the same numbers are 63% vs. 37%.</li>
</ul>



<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-2 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="520" height="623" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Wide-grip-bench-press-1rm-triceps-vs-chest-and-shoulder-contribution.png?resize=520%2C623&amp;ssl=1" alt="Wide grip bench press 1rm triceps vs chest and shoulder contribution" class="wp-image-8832" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Wide-grip-bench-press-1rm-triceps-vs-chest-and-shoulder-contribution.png?w=520&amp;ssl=1 520w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Wide-grip-bench-press-1rm-triceps-vs-chest-and-shoulder-contribution.png?resize=250%2C300&amp;ssl=1 250w" sizes="(max-width: 520px) 100vw, 520px" /></figure>
</div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="520" height="623" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Close-grip-bench-press-1rm-triceps-vs-chest-and-shoulder-contribution.png?resize=520%2C623&amp;ssl=1" alt="Close grip bench press 1rm triceps vs chest and shoulder contribution" class="wp-image-8835" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Close-grip-bench-press-1rm-triceps-vs-chest-and-shoulder-contribution.png?w=520&amp;ssl=1 520w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Close-grip-bench-press-1rm-triceps-vs-chest-and-shoulder-contribution.png?resize=250%2C300&amp;ssl=1 250w" sizes="(max-width: 520px) 100vw, 520px" /></figure>
</div>
</div>



<p>The maximum grip width allowed in powerlifting is 81 cm between your hands. A powerlifting bar has rings marking this distance, and so your maximum grip width is when your index fingers cover these rings. </p>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><strong><em>Read more:&nbsp;</em></strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/wide-vs-close-grip-bench-press-strength-ratio-muscles-worked/"><em>Bench Press Grip Width: Wide vs Close-Grip</em></a></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-hand-position">Hand Position</h3>



<p>There are two major points to consider regarding how you grip the bar:</p>



<p><strong>1. Your thumb must be on the opposing side of your other fingers.</strong> Meaning that you grip around the bar. I strongly recommend that you avoid using a thumbless grip. Firstly, it is not allowed in powerlifting. Secondly, it is also known as the <em>suicide grip</em>. This is because you can easily slip and drop the bar with a high risk of injury. Don&#8217;t use it.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="453" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?resize=700%2C453&#038;ssl=1" alt="" class="wp-image-13441" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?resize=1024%2C663&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?resize=300%2C194&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?resize=768%2C497&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?resize=1536%2C994&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?w=1862&amp;ssl=1 1862w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Bench-press-grip-vs-thumbless-grip.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Recommended grip with thumb around the bar to the left. Non-recommended thumbless &#8220;suicide&#8221; grip to the right.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p><strong>2. The bar should rest in a comfortable place.</strong> As you&#8217;re lifting heavier and heavier weights, this might become tricky. For most people, the most comfortable and stable position is to hold the bar as close to the base of your palm as possible, i.e. close to or directly above your wrist. This minimizes the leverage the bar works on your wrist and makes it easier to hold.</p>



<p>Combining the two points (keeping your thumb around the bar, while still keeping it low in your hand) above might be tricky, and one solution is to slightly rotate your hands inwards so that the barbell rests in a diagonal line in your palm.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="864" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Barbell-bench-press-lying-in-diagonal-line-in-palm.jpg?resize=700%2C864&#038;ssl=1" alt="Barbell bench press lying in diagonal line in palm" class="wp-image-13444" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Barbell-bench-press-lying-in-diagonal-line-in-palm.jpg?resize=830%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 830w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Barbell-bench-press-lying-in-diagonal-line-in-palm.jpg?resize=243%2C300&amp;ssl=1 243w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Barbell-bench-press-lying-in-diagonal-line-in-palm.jpg?resize=768%2C947&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Barbell-bench-press-lying-in-diagonal-line-in-palm.jpg?resize=1245%2C1536&amp;ssl=1 1245w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Barbell-bench-press-lying-in-diagonal-line-in-palm.jpg?w=1250&amp;ssl=1 1250w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">I have rotated my hand slightly inwards so that the barbell is resting in a diagonal line across my palm. Notice how low the barbell is placed in my hand; as close to the wrist as possible.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Don&#8217;t keep a completely straight wrist. This puts you at risk of losing balance, tilting your wrist forward, and dropping the barbell. Instead, tilt your wrist back slightly, to better rest the barbell in your hand.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="458" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?resize=700%2C458&#038;ssl=1" alt="" class="wp-image-13447" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?resize=1024%2C670&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?resize=300%2C196&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?resize=768%2C502&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?resize=1536%2C1005&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?resize=2048%2C1340&amp;ssl=1 2048w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Straight-vs-tilted-wrist.jpg?w=2100&amp;ssl=1 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Avoid keeping a straight wrist like to the left. Instead, slightly tilt your wrist backward like on the right.</figcaption></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="elbow-position">Elbow Position</h3>



<p>Where should your elbows be during the lift: close to your body or out to the sides?</p>



<p>It depends on your grip width, your anatomy, and also your purpose with bench pressing.</p>



<ul>
<li>Grip width generally determines elbow position, with a wide grip typically leading to your elbows pointing out, and a close grip leading to your elbows being closer to your sides.</li>



<li>If you bench press in order to grow your&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-muscles-exercises-workout/">chest muscles</a>, a rather wide elbow position and a wide grip is effective.</li>



<li>If you bench press in order to train your&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/triceps-muscles-exercises-workout/">triceps</a>, a close grip with your elbows close to your sides is effective.</li>



<li>If you want to lift as much weight as possible, something in between (around 45° to your sides) is probably best. You will, however, have to experiment for yourself and see what feels the best and suits your body.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="shoulder-blades">Shoulder Blades</h3>



<p>Your shoulders are mobile joints. But when you&#8217;re bench pressing, you want to trade some of that mobility for stability.</p>



<p>Therefore, you will want to <strong>pull your shoulder blades down and back</strong> before you unrack the bar, and keep them in this position throughout the lift. Visualize that you&#8217;re putting them in your back pockets, but on the opposing side, i.e. your right shoulder blade into your left back pocket, and vice versa.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="422" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=700%2C422&#038;ssl=1" alt="Shoulder blades forward in the bench press" class="wp-image-13451" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=1024%2C618&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=300%2C181&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=768%2C464&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=1536%2C927&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?w=1938&amp;ssl=1 1938w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-forward-in-the-bench-press.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">In this pic, my shoulder blades are slouched forward. Don&#8217;t bench like this.</figcaption></figure></div>

<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="422" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=700%2C422&#038;ssl=1" alt="Shoulder blades down and back in the bench press" class="wp-image-13452" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=1024%2C618&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=300%2C181&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=768%2C464&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?resize=1536%2C927&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?w=1938&amp;ssl=1 1938w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Shoulder-blades-down-and-back-in-the-bench-press.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Here, I&#8217;ve pulled my shoulder blades back and down. Bench like this.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Note that you will have to &#8220;set&#8221; your shoulder blades in this manner before you even unrack the bar, because when you&#8217;ve got a heavy bar in your hands, it&#8217;s too late. Then, your shoulder blades stay in this position until you re-rack the barbell again. That means you will keep your shoulder blades retracted and pulled down even as you&#8217;re pressing the bar up, which might require some practice.</p>



<p>Pulling your shoulder blades down and back and keeping them in this position during your entire set will protect your shoulder joints and provide you with a solid base, enabling you to lift more.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="foot-position">Foot Position</h3>



<p>The goal of your foot position is to keep you stable and support you throughout the lift. You will want to place your feet firmly on the floor and keep them still throughout the lift. Don&#8217;t fidget with your feet, as that will rob you of any stability.</p>



<p>In IPF powerlifting, you are required to keep your whole feet planted on the floor. In other federations, or if you&#8217;re just bench pressing in the gym, this is not required. For some people, being able to go up on their toes enables them to create a higher arch, which in turn allows them to lift more weight, despite the relative loss of stability from only keeping part of your foot on the floor.</p>



<p>In general, I recommend that you place your feet somewhere where you feel comfortable, stable, where you are able to produce some manner of leg drive. If you don&#8217;t know where to start, try placing your feet about hip-width apart, with your legs bent at a 90-degree angle or slightly more.</p>



<p>Don&#8217;t move your feet around after you&#8217;ve unracked the bar. Plant them, unrack, and then keep your feet still until you&#8217;ve racked the bar again. An exception is if you go up on your toes when you&#8217;re unracking, but in that case, plant your feet on the floor again as soon as you&#8217;re in position.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="leg-drive">Leg Drive</h3>



<p>Perhaps no more concept has been more misunderstood or over-complicated in the bench press than that of the <strong>leg drive.</strong></p>



<p>Leg drive simply means that you apply a slight <em>push </em>with your legs. This will contract and tense your leg muscles, which in turn makes your whole body a little harder and more stable. And as the bench press is a lift that thrives on stability, you will likely be able to lift a little more weight because of this.</p>



<p>That&#8217;s all it is.</p>



<p>The leg drive <strong>is not</strong> a magical way of using force applied with your legs into the floor to lift the bar. That is simply not how mechanics work.</p>



<p>Once again, an exception: if you by &#8220;leg drive&#8221; mean that you are heaving your entire body upwards by pushing against the floor, then yes: you will have actually used your legs to lift the bar. But seeing as this is not allowed in <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/powerlifting-competition-attempt-calculator/">powerlifting competitions</a> and is not a bench press technique I recommend for anyone, I think we can ignore this concept.</p>



<p>To reiterate: the point of the leg drive is to stabilize your legs and torso, and thereby improve performance in the lift.</p>



<p>But how do you do this? How do you use leg drive in the bench press?</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>What you should <span style="text-decoration: underline;">not</span> do</strong> is to push your feet <strong>down</strong> into the floor. This will only lead to you lifting your butt off the bench, which is, once again, not allowed in competition and not a technique I recommend for anyone.</li>



<li><strong>What you should do</strong> instead, is to push with your legs like if you tried to slide yourself over the head end of the bench. Meaning, you should apply force <em>horizontally</em> with your feet, away from the foot end of the bench.</li>
</ul>



<p>Not that you should only apply just enough force so that your feet don&#8217;t move. Your feet should still be completely still throughout the entire lift. You&#8217;re only pushing just enough to stay within the limits of friction, in order to tense your legs and stabilize your body.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="bench-press-arch">Bench Press Arch</h3>



<p>The bench press arch is the topic of many heated discussions. I&#8217;ll avoid going into the politics of it, and instead focus on what it is and what it does.</p>



<p>Arching in the bench press refers to the practice of bending your upper body and spine backward; you&#8217;re creating an arch with your upper body.</p>



<p>This has several effects on the lift, of which the most significant is that you <strong>shorten your range of motion.</strong></p>



<p>More specifically, you remove the weakest part of the bench press range of motion, namely the bottom part of the lift. This fact alone enables most people to lift significantly more weight when they are in an arched position, contrary to when they are lying completely flat on the bench.</p>



<p>A study of highly trained powerlifters showed they could lift 4.2 kg or 9 pounds (3.5%) more weight in a 1RM with an arched back than a flat back.<span id='easy-footnote-4-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-4-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38551927/&quot;&gt;J Strength Cond Res. 2024 Mar 29. Flat-Back vs. Arched-Back Bench Press: Examining the Different Techniques Performed by Power Athletes.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>4</sup></a></span>



<p>But cutting the range of motion short isn&#8217;t the only thing that happens when you arch.</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>It stabilizes your shoulder blades. </strong>By tilting your body in an arch, you shift more of your weight onto your shoulder blades which helps to keep them in place during the lift. Many lifters experience greater shoulder stability when lifting because of this.</li>



<li><strong>Less shoulder mobility required.</strong> Not everyone has the shoulder mobility required to lower a barbell down to their chest when they are lying flat on a bench. By elevating their torso with an arch they don&#8217;t have to lower the bar as far, which decreases the required range of motion of the shoulder joints.</li>



<li><strong>More effective use of your pecs (maybe).</strong> Your pectoralis major are large, fan-shaped muscles, whose muscle fibers to a large extent are downward (towards your abdomen) oriented. It is possible that when you are pressing at a slight decline, which is essentially what happens when you arch, your pecs are working in a stronger position.</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>So should you use an arch in the bench press?</strong></p>



<p>It depends.</p>



<p>I think that most lifters benefit from a small arch in the bench press. It places the shoulders in a little more stable position and generally seems to make the shoulder feel better for a lot of people.</p>



<p>If you are competing in powerlifting and want to lift as much weight as possible within the rules, then you should definitely explore arching and see how it affects your performance. Not everyone will lift more with an arch, but many do.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="pause-or-touch-and-go">Should You Pause With the Bar on Your Chest, or &#8220;Touch and Go&#8221;?</h3>



<p>In most powerlifting federations, you must pause the bar on your chest when you are competing. When the referee gives the “Press!” command, you press the bar up to straight arms. Therefore, if you are training for powerlifting, it is a good idea to incorporate at least some amount of training with a pause on your chest, especially in the time leading up to competitions.</p>



<p>If you don’t train for powerlifting, pausing in the bottom position is optional. It probably doesn&#8217;t have any additional benefits for <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/build-muscle/">building muscle</a> compared to a controlled reversal. It might, however, help you improve your technique because you slow things down and get more practice in one of the hardest parts of the lift. Similarly, pausing can improve your strength off your chest.</p>



<p>Bench pressing without a pause on your chest is called <em>touch and go</em>. You lower the bar down and touch your chest, without neither pausing nor bouncing, and then press the bar up again.</p>



<p>Avoid bouncing the bar on your chest. It puts you at risk of injuring your ribs or your sternum, which can put a stop to your training for a long time.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="bar-path">Bar Path</h3>



<p>The barbell does not move in a straight line in the bench press, but rather in a slope towards your feet.</p>



<p>Research has shown that novices typically bench press in a different bar path than elite bench pressers do, especially on the ascent.<span id='easy-footnote-5-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-5-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6493018/&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 1984 Aug;16(4):376-81. Kinematic factors influencing performance and injury risk in the bench press exercise.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>5</sup></a></span>



<ul>
<li>Novice bench pressers, benching around 220 lb / 100 kg, typically begin by pushing the bar <strong>straight up</strong> and then towards the head.</li>



<li>Elite bench pressers (benching 400 lb or more) typically begin by <strong>pushing the bar towards the head </strong>and then straight up.</li>
</ul>



<p>Here&#8217;s an example of a typical novice bar path (to the left) compared with the bar path of two elite bench pressers (in the center and to the right). </p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="705" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Bench-Press-Bar-Path.jpg?resize=700%2C705&#038;ssl=1" alt="Bench Press Bar Path" class="wp-image-13250" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Bench-Press-Bar-Path.jpg?w=715&amp;ssl=1 715w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Bench-Press-Bar-Path.jpg?resize=298%2C300&amp;ssl=1 298w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/Bench-Press-Bar-Path.jpg?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<p>It might be worth experimenting with different bar paths, and especially shifting the weight closer to your shoulders on the way up. Make sure to use safety racks when doing this, though, so that you don&#8217;t misgroove too much and land the bar on your face.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="bench-press-variations"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Bench_Press_Variations"></span>Bench Press Variations<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>In this section, we&#8217;ll go over some of the most popular <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-variations/">bench press variations</a>.</p>



<ol>
<li><a href="#Close-Grip-Bench-Press">Close-Grip Bench Press</a></li>



<li><a href="#Feet-Up-Bench-Press">Feet-Up Bench Press</a></li>



<li><a href="#Close-Grip-Feet-Up-Bench-Press">Close-Grip Feet-Up Bench Press</a></li>



<li><a href="#Incline-Bench-Press">Incline Bench Press</a></li>



<li><a href="#Decline-Bench-Press">Decline Bench Press</a></li>



<li><a href="#Floor-Press">Floor Press</a></li>



<li><a href="#Smith-Machine-Bench-Press">Smith Machine Bench Press</a></li>
</ol>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Close-Grip-Bench-Press">1. Close-Grip Bench Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-bench-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Close-grip-bench-press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Close-Grip Bench Press" class="wp-image-10667" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-bench-press/">Close-Grip Bench Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-bench-press/">close-grip bench press</a> might be one of the most popular bench press variations out there. This exercise shifts more of the work toward your triceps muscles: In a wide-grip bench press, your triceps contribute around 22% of the force in the sticking region. In the close-grip bench press, your triceps contribute around 37% (almost double!) of the force.</p>



<p>The close-grip bench press is especially useful for working your triceps and getting stronger in your lockout, but it really is a great general exercise for increasing your upper body strength.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Feet-Up-Bench-Press">2. Feet-Up Bench Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/feet-up-bench-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Feet-Up-Bench-Press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Feet-Up Bench Press" class="wp-image-10669" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/feet-up-bench-press/">Feet-Up Bench Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/feet-up-bench-press/">feet-up bench press </a>is a chest exercise that has seemingly gained popularity over the last years, perhaps as a response to the popularization of bench press arches. The feet-up bench greatly inhibits the amount of arch you can create with your lower back, and thus forces you into a more flat bench press technique. This leads to a longer range of motion, which, in turn, might benefit both your strength gains and <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/build-muscle/">muscle growth</a>.</p>



<p>Another benefit of the feet-up bench press is that as you cannot rely on your legs for support, you will have to create a stable base using your upper body and torso alone. After you&#8217;ve learned how to do this, you can then benefit from this extra stability in your regular bench press.</p>



<p>Because you cannot use as heavy weights as in the traditional bench press, the feet-up bench press acts as a form of autoregulation in your training, suitable for light workouts.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Close-Grip-Feet-Up-Bench-Press">3. Close-Grip Feet-Up Bench Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-feet-up-bench-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Close-Grip-Feet-Up-Bench-Press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Close-Grip Feet-Up Bench Press" class="wp-image-2628" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-feet-up-bench-press/">Close-Grip Feet-Up Bench Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/close-grip-feet-up-bench-press/">close-grip feet-up bench press</a> is a combination of the two previous exercises: the close-grip bench press and the feet-up bench press. Therefore, it combines the pros and cons of both of these.</p>



<p>Greater triceps emphasis, more training for your lockout, and stability training are some of the pros of this exercise.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Incline-Bench-Press">4. Incline Bench Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/incline-bench-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Incline-Bench-Press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Incline Bench Press" class="wp-image-2386" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/incline-bench-press/">Incline Bench Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/incline-bench-press/">incline bench press </a>is a variation that emphasizes your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/upper-chest-exercises/">upper chest muscles</a> and anterior deltoids. Typically, a slight decline of about 30° is enough to elicit this effect.<span id='easy-footnote-6-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-6-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33049982/&quot;&gt;Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2020 Oct 8;17(19):7339. Effect of Five Bench Inclinations on the Electromyographic Activity of the Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoid, and Triceps Brachii during the Bench Press Exercise.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>6</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-7-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-7-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25799093/&quot;&gt;Comparative Study Eur J Sport Sci. 2016;16(3):309-16. Epub 2015 Mar 23.&lt;br&gt;Influence of bench angle on upper extremity muscular activation during bench press exercise.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>7</sup></a></span>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="623" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?resize=700%2C623&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscle activation in incline bench press" class="wp-image-10186" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?resize=1024%2C911&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?resize=300%2C267&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?resize=768%2C683&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?resize=1536%2C1366&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?resize=2048%2C1821&amp;ssl=1 2048w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Muscle-activation-in-incline-bench.png?w=2100&amp;ssl=1 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Muscle activation when bench pressing at different inclines.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>A popular variation of the incline bench press is to trade the barbell for a pair of dumbbells and perform <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/dumbbell-incline-press/">incline dumbbell presses</a> instead. Many people feel that the freedom of motion of the dumbbells enable them to lift in a more comfortable movement path.</p>



<p>If you usually train the bench press with a big arch, incline bench presses might be a good way to give your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/upper-chest-exercises/">upper pecs</a> some more love.</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href="http://5 diff">5 Differences Between Incline Bench Press vs Flat Bench Press</a></em></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Decline-Bench-Press">5. Decline Bench Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/decline-bench-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Decline-Bench-Press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Decline Bench Press" class="wp-image-2588" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/decline-bench-press/">Decline Bench Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/decline-bench-press/">decline bench press</a> is a variation that emphasizes your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-chest-exercises/">lower chest muscles</a>. This exercise comes with a higher injury risk than the traditional bench press:</p>



<ol>
<li>Because your head i tilted downward, the blood pressure in your brain will probably reach higher levels than normal. This might or might not be dangerous, but it is something to be aware of and consider depending on your circumstances.</li>



<li>Because of the downward angle, it is extremely important that you always have a spotter or correctly adjusted safety racks to catch the bar. Otherwise, you might end up in a situation where you are pinned under the bar, and cannot roll it down your legs.</li>
</ol>



<p>Seeing as the traditional flat bench press already works your lower chest well, the increased risk of this exercise might not be worth it. Perhaps try some <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bar-dip/">dips</a> or downward-angled <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-cable-chest-fly/">cable chest flyes</a> instead?</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em><strong>Read More:</strong> <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-chest-exercises/">The 10 Best Lower Chest Exercises to Build Your Pecs</a></em></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Floor-Press">6. Floor Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/floor-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Floor-Press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Floor Press" class="wp-image-2593" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/floor-press/">Floor Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/floor-press/">floor press</a> is a bench press variation that I don&#8217;t see performed very often nowadays, perhaps because of the shift in popularity away from equipped bench pressing towards classic (&#8220;raw&#8221;) bench pressing.</p>



<p>For an equipped bench presser, the floor press offers a great way to train the lockout with heavy loads. It can also be a good alternative when you want to limit your range of motion in the case of a pec tear or pec pain.</p>



<p>A drawback of the floor press is that setting up can be a challenge. If your power rack doesn&#8217;t go down far enough for you to unrack the bar from it (like mine), you will have to place the bar on boxes, have a spotter hand it to you, or simply roll it up your body and heave it up to get into the starting position.</p>



<p>An easier option to set up would be the board press, where you place a board on your chest to limit the range of motion.</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><strong><em>Read more: </em></strong><em><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/floor-press-vs-bench-press/">Floor Press vs. Bench Press for Strength: Benefits &amp; Differences</a></em></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="Smith-Machine-Bench-Press">7. Smith Machine Bench Press</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/smith-machine-bench-press/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/smith-machine-bench-press.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Smith Machine Bench Press" class="wp-image-2675" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/smith-machine-bench-press/">Smith Machine Bench Press</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The last bench press variation we&#8217;ll cover in this section is the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/smith-machine-bench-press/">smith machine bench press</a>. This exercise certainly comes with its own sets of pros and cons.</p>



<p>On the pro side is the extra stability, which might enable you to work your muscles a little harder than usual because you don&#8217;t have to worry about balance.</p>



<p>On the negative side, we have the fact that a normal, free barbell bench press doesn&#8217;t move in a vertical bar path (see the section on <a href="#bar-path">bar path</a> for more info). The smith machine, however, forces you to work in a straight line, which an experienced bench presser might perceive as uncomfortable.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Bench_Press_FAQ"></span>Bench Press FAQ<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Here are answers to some of the most common questions we hear regarding the bench press.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-what-muscles-are-worked-in-the-bench-press">What Muscles Are Worked In the Bench Press?</h3>



<p>The bench press will primarily work your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-muscles-exercises-workout/">chest</a> and <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/front-delts-muscle-exercises-workout/">front deltoids</a>. Your triceps are worked secondary, typically growing half as much from bench pressing as your chest and front delts do.<span id='easy-footnote-8-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-8-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3831787/&quot;&gt;Interv Med Appl Sci. 2012 Dec; 4(4): 217–220. Time course for arm and chest muscle thickness changes following bench press training.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>8</sup></a></span>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="669" height="606" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Chest-muscle-growth-from-bench-press-training.png?resize=669%2C606&#038;ssl=1" alt="chest and triceps are worked by the bench press" class="wp-image-4731" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Chest-muscle-growth-from-bench-press-training.png?w=669&amp;ssl=1 669w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Chest-muscle-growth-from-bench-press-training.png?resize=300%2C272&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 669px) 100vw, 669px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<p>You can read more about this in our article: <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-is-not-enough-for-maximal-triceps-growth/">Does the Bench Press Work Your Triceps?</a></p>



<p>Your chest muscles, or pectoral muscles, make up one of the largest muscle groups of your upper body, and the bench press is, therefore, a great exercise for adding muscle mass to this area.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-is-bench-pressing-bad-for-your-shoulders">Is Bench Pressing Bad for Your Shoulders?</h3>



<p>No, that would be a misleading statement. The bench press is an exercise that <em>loads </em>your shoulders. Thus, proper loading can strengthen your shoulder joint and make it more resilient towards injury. If you train with excessive volume or loads, however, you risk doing too much, too soon, which can result in an injury.</p>



<p>The bench press is a tool that strengthens your shoulders if used correctly.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Why Do I Get Shoulder Pain From Bench Pressing?</h3>



<p>There can be many reasons why you get <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/shoulder-pain-when-bench-pressing/">shoulder pain from bench pressing</a>, two of the most likely culprits being: doing too much too soon, or using a technique that doesn&#8217;t suit your body.</p>



<ul>
<li>If you believe you might have done too much, too soon, ease up on bench presses for a while and consider your training volume. Perhaps try one of our <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-programs/">bench press programs</a> for inspiration?</li>



<li>If you suspect that your technique might be the problem, read our <a href="#bench-press-form-detailed-instructions">detailed instructions on how to bench press</a> and try different techniques.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Do Push-Ups Increase Bench Press?</h3>



<p>Yes, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/push-up/">push-ups</a> work the same muscles as the bench press (= your chest, front deltoid, and triceps) in a similar movement, and can therefore be used as an <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/accessory-exercises-to-improve-bench-press/">bench press accessory exercise</a>.</p>



<p>Personally, doing daily push-ups played a large part when I increased my bench press from 140 to 162.5 kg (308 to 358 lb). At the time, I did a weekly bench press session where I just worked up to a heavy top set and then stopped. Then on a daily basis (about six days a week), I did 10 sets of 10 strict push-ups. This was at a time when I could do about 30 strict, deep push-ups.</p>



<p>A study from Japan had young, recreationally trained men train push-ups for eight weeks to see how it affected their chest and triceps muscle thickness and their bench press 1RM.<span id='easy-footnote-9-2084' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-9-2084' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1728869X17301028&quot;&gt;J Exerc Sci Fit. 2017 Jun;15(1):37-42. Low-load bench press and push-up induce similar muscle hypertrophy and strength gain.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>9</sup></a></span> They did push-ups two times per week, with three sets to failure each workout. After eight weeks, they had increased their chest muscle thickness by 18%, triceps thickness by 10%, and their 1RM in the bench press by 5%. Note that this was a group seemingly unused to the bench press. I suspect that if they would have had just a little skill practice in the bench press during these eight weeks, they would have increased their strength far more.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-want-to-get-stronger-in-the-bench-press">Want to Get Stronger in the Bench Press?</h2>



<p>Looking for a training program to build a big bench?</p>



<p>Check out our <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press-programs/">bench press programs</a>!</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center">***</p>

.mo-optin-fields-wrapper .checkbox-field, html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .mo-optin-form-wrapper .mo-optin-fields-wrapper .radio-field, html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .select-field { text-align: left; padding: 6px; } html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .mo-optin-form-wrapper .mo-optin-fields-wrapper .checkbox-field label, html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .mo-optin-form-wrapper .mo-optin-fields-wrapper .radio-field label { display: block; text-align: left; margin-top: 6px; } html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .mo-optin-form-wrapper .mo-optin-fields-wrapper .checkbox-field label input, html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .mo-optin-form-wrapper .mo-optin-fields-wrapper .radio-field label input { margin-right: 5px; vertical-align: middle; } html div#hNRVySBubX .mo-optin-form-container .mo-optin-form-wrapper .mo-optin-fields-wrapper .select-field select { width: 100%; } html div#hNRVySBubX <article id="post-8652" class="post-8652 page type-page status-publish mv-content-wrapper" itemtype="https://schema.org/CreativeWork" itemscope>
	<div class="inside-article">
		
			<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">How to Deadlift: Muscles Worked &#038; Proper Form</h1>			</header>

			
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="text">
			<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Deadlift.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift exercise technique" class="wp-image-4787" data-recalc-dims="1"/></figure></div>


<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-1 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift">Muscles Worked in the Deadlift</h2>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-muscles-worked.png?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift muscles worked" class="wp-image-8537" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-muscles-worked.png?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-muscles-worked.png?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-muscles-worked.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-muscles-worked.png?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-muscles-worked.png?w=1125&amp;ssl=1 1125w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-primary-muscles-worked">Primary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">Glutes</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-back-muscles-exercises-workout/">Lower Back</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-secondary-muscles-worked">Secondary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/quad-muscles-exercises-workout/">Quads</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hamstring-muscles-exercises-workout/">Hamstrings</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hip-adductor-muscles-exercises-workout/">Adductors</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/trapezius-muscle-exercises-workout/">Trapezius</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/forearm-flexors-and-grip-muscles-exercises-workout/">Forearm Flexors</a></li>
</ul>
</div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-deadlift-with-proper-form">How to Deadlift with Proper Form</h2>



<ol>
<li>Step up close to the bar so that it is about over the middle of your foot.</li>



<li>Inhale, lean forward, and grip the bar.</li>



<li>Hold your breath, brace your core slightly, and lift the bar.</li>



<li>Pull the bar close to your body, with a straight back, until you are standing straight.</li>



<li>Lower the bar back to the ground with control.</li>



<li>Take another breath, and repeat for reps.</li>
</ol>



<p><em>Text and graphics from the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">StrengthLog </a>app.</em></p>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/deadlift-strength-standards-kg/">Deadlift strength standards in kg</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/deadlift-strength-standards-lb/">Deadlift strength standards in lb</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>



<figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-video is-provider-youtube wp-block-embed-youtube"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper">
<iframe title="How to Deadlift in Five Steps" width="700" height="394" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/PgEsLQI522A?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" allowfullscreen></iframe>
</div><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><em>Watch the five-step deadlift setup.</em></figcaption></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-introduction-to-the-deadlift">Introduction to the Deadlift</h2>



<p><strong>Deadlifting </strong>is one of the wisest things you can do with a barbell.</p>



<p>It strengthens your body from head to toe and puts on slabs of muscle all over you. Deadlift training builds a resilient back and hardens your body into injury-proof armor.</p>



<p>It is a competitive lift in powerlifting (which I compete in) and is used in athletes’ training in almost every sport.</p>



<p><strong>In this guide you&#8217;ll learn: </strong></p>



<ul>
<li><strong>How to deadlift </strong>effectively and safely.</li>



<li><strong>How to train the deadlift </strong>to get big and strong.</li>
</ul>



<p>We&#8217;ll begin with a simple demonstration and a general explanation of the deadlift technique.</p>



<p>The deadlift is performed by simply lifting a barbell off the ground to the level of your hips, and then lowering it back to the ground.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
