<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="467" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C467&#038;ssl=1" alt="How to deadlift" class="wp-image-269" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C200&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift.jpg?resize=768%2C512&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift.jpg?w=1500&amp;ssl=1 1500w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<p>Some trainers over-complicate the deadlift (and the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squat</a> and <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press/">bench press</a>) to the point of rocket science.</p>



<p>While I am obsessively interested in the deadlift and will pour much of that into this article, I also know that less is more when you&#8217;re learning a new lift.</p>



<p>In reality, deadlifts are extremely simple to do.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Preparation</h3>



<ul>
<li><strong>Set a bar</strong> on the floor, preferably loaded with full-sized weight plates (45 cm / 17.72 in).</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">How to Deadlift with Proper Form:</h3>



<ol>
<li><strong>Step up close</strong> to the bar so that it is positioned about over the middle of your foot.</li>



<li><strong>Bend over and grip</strong> the bar with hands about shoulder-width apart.</li>



<li><strong>Inhale, brace your core, and lift</strong> the bar by extending your hips and knees.</li>



<li><strong>Pull the bar close</strong> to your body until you are standing straight up, with hips and knees locked out.</li>



<li><strong>Lower the bar</strong> back to the ground.</li>
</ol>



<p>For a demonstration of both the set-up and the lift, here&#8217;s a video of me deadlifting 260 kg in a powerlifting competition last year:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-video is-provider-youtube wp-block-embed-youtube wp-embed-aspect-4-3 wp-has-aspect-ratio"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper">
<iframe loading="lazy" title="Daniel Richter Deadlifts 260 kg" width="700" height="525" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/uJwNTgbDLz0?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" allowfullscreen></iframe>
</div></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Major Muscles Worked in the Deadlift</h2>



<p>Which muscles does the deadlift work? </p>



<p>You&#8217;ve already seen this once, but let&#8217;s recap quickly.</p>



<p>These are the muscles that need to be strong in order to be strong in the deadlift, and it is the muscles that primarily (and secondarily) will grow and get stronger from deadlift training.</p>



<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-2 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow"><div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscles worked in the deadlift" class="wp-image-8507" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Muscles-worked-in-the-deadlift.jpg?w=1125&amp;ssl=1 1125w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Major muscles worked in the deadlift.</figcaption></figure></div></div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Primary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">Glutes</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-back-muscles-exercises-workout/">Lower Back</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Secondary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/quad-muscles-exercises-workout/">Quads</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hamstring-muscles-exercises-workout/">Hamstrings</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hip-adductor-muscles-exercises-workout/">Adductors</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/trapezius-muscle-exercises-workout/">Trapezius</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/forearm-flexors-and-grip-muscles-exercises-workout/">Forearm Flexors</a></li>
</ul>



<p></p>
</div>
</div>



<p>While more muscles are involved as stabilizers and synergists, these are the main muscles involved in producing the force necessary to lift the bar.<span id='easy-footnote-1-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-1-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10912892&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 2000 Jul;32(7):1265-75. A three-dimensional biomechanical analysis of sumo and conventional style deadlifts.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>1</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-2-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-2-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11932579&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 2002 Apr;34(4):682-8. An electromyographic analysis of sumo and conventional style deadlifts.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>2</sup></a></span>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-deadlift-training-programs-and-optimal-technique">Deadlift Training Programs and Optimal Technique</h2>



<p>That was the basics<strong> </strong>on how to deadlift, and you are more than ready to start practicing the lift with a light weight.</p>



<p>The deadlift takes years and years to master, so you might as well get started.</p>



<p>For the rest of this article, we&#8217;ll delve into the more advanced stuff:</p>



<ul>
<li>Optimizing your technique</li>



<li>How to get stronger in the deadlift</li>



<li>Deadlift training programs for the &#8230;
<ul>
<li>Beginner</li>



<li>Intermediate</li>



<li>Advanced</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>



<p>Read on, friend.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Optimizing Your Deadlift Technique</h2>



<p>With the basics out of the way, let&#8217;s look at how you can optimize your deadlift technique for <em>you</em>. How do different technique alterations affect your deadlift performance, what muscles it works, and its safety?</p>



<p>Probably the biggest technical decision is whether you should deadlift &#8230;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Conventional or Sumo?</h3>



<p>The two common ways to deadlift are the conventional and <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/sumo-deadlift/">sumo deadlift</a>.</p>



<ul>
<li><strong><em>Conventional</em></strong> is the more common variant of the two, as its name indicates. In the conventional deadlift, you grip the bar with your arms <em>outside </em>your knees, and you typically keep your feet about hip-width apart.</li>



<li><strong><em>Sumo</em></strong> is probably mostly used inside the sport of powerlifting and gets its name from its similarity to the sumo wrestler&#8217;s stance. In the sumo deadlift, you grip the bar with your arms <em>inside </em>your knees, and your stance can be so wide that your toes almost touch the weight plates.</li>
</ul>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="467" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift-conventional-vs-sumo-starting-position.jpg?resize=700%2C467&#038;ssl=1" alt="Conventional vs sumo deadlift technique" class="wp-image-294" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift-conventional-vs-sumo-starting-position.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift-conventional-vs-sumo-starting-position.jpg?resize=300%2C200&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift-conventional-vs-sumo-starting-position.jpg?resize=768%2C512&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift-conventional-vs-sumo-starting-position.jpg?w=1500&amp;ssl=1 1500w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Deadlift-conventional-vs-sumo-starting-position.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Starting position of the conventional deadlift (left) and sumo deadlift (right).</figcaption></figure></div>


<h4 class="wp-block-heading">Biomechanical Differences Between Conventional and Sumo Deadlifts</h4>



<ul>
<li><strong>Trunk angle</strong>. The conventional deadlift leads to a greater forward lean of your torso, while the sumo deadlifts let you keep your torso a bit closer to vertical. This means sumo deadlifts generally are a bit easier on your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-back-muscles-exercises-workout/">lower back</a> – about 10% easier.<span id='easy-footnote-3-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-3-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1758295&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 1991 Oct;23(10):1179-86. Lumbar spine loads during the lifting of extremely heavy weights.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>3</sup></a></span></li>



<li><strong>Knee extension.</strong> Your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/quad-muscles-exercises-workout/">quads </a>pick up the slack left from your lower back in the sumo deadlift. While conventional deadlifts are pretty easy on your quads, the sumo taxes them rather hard.</li>



<li><strong>Hip extension.</strong> Hip extension demands are quite similar in the two styles, even if they do target the hip in slightly different ways: sumo deadlifts require more hip adduction, while conventional deadlifts require more hip extension in the sagittal plane (front to back). This does not, however, result in any difference in <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">glute </a>activation between the two.</li>



<li><strong>Total work</strong> and energy expenditure is higher in the conventional deadlift due to the greater vertical distance the bar travels. This should not be confused with the peak force required to complete the lift, however. Your ability to produce force is what will limit your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>in the deadlift, not the total amount of work done.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Which Style is the Strongest: Sumo or Conventional?</h3>



<p>That will probably depend on <em>you</em>, buddy.</p>



<p>Different body shapes and sizes, muscle insertions and origins, limb length and pelvises, strengths and weaknesses will all contribute to wether conventional or sumo deadlifts suits you better.</p>



<p>One clue, however, might simply be <em>how big</em> you are. <a href="https://mystrengthbook.com/blog/the-math-behind-the-2016-ipf-classic-world-powerlifting-championships/">MyStrengthBook </a>made a brilliant job at analyzing and presenting the math from 2016 years IPF Classic Powerlifting World Championship, and found a strong correlation between bodyweight and deadlift style for both sexes.</p>



<p>The lower the weight class, the greater the number of athletes pulling with a sumo style, and vice versa. The breaking point (where the number of lifters pulling with each style is 50/50) seems to be at about ~90 kg for men and ~60 kg for women.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="401" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Conventional-or-sumo-deadlift-men.png?resize=700%2C401&#038;ssl=1" alt="" class="wp-image-315" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Conventional-or-sumo-deadlift-men.png?w=760&amp;ssl=1 760w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Conventional-or-sumo-deadlift-men.png?resize=300%2C172&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="373" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Conventional-or-sumo-deadlift-women.png?resize=700%2C373&#038;ssl=1" alt="" class="wp-image-316" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Conventional-or-sumo-deadlift-women.png?w=760&amp;ssl=1 760w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Conventional-or-sumo-deadlift-women.png?resize=300%2C160&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<p>Now, this might be influenced by a number of factors (such as culture), but one possible explanation for this lies in the fact that conventional deadlifts are about <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1758295">10% more demanding of your lower back</a>. A bigger athlete probably has a bigger trunk, which in and of itself will act like a belt or cushion of sorts. This could theoretically aid in the conventional style by alleviating some of the work required of the spinal erectors.</p>



<p>A recent study measured the anthropometrics of 47 participants without any prior experience with deadlifting, and, after some introductory training to the two styles, tested their <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM in both conventional and sumo deadlifts. </a><span id='easy-footnote-4-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-4-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.jssm.org/hf.php?id=jssm-18-448.xml&quot;&gt;J Sports Sci Med. 2019 Aug 1;18(3):448-453. eCollection 2019 Sep. Anthropometrical Determinants of Deadlift Variant Performance.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>4</sup></a></span> The only anthropometric predictor of which style was the strongest was their sitting height to total height ratio, which correlated with their sumo deadlift to conventional deadlift performance.</p>



<p>Put simply: participants with longer torsos were more likely to be stronger in sumo deadlifts than conventional.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Foot Position</h3>



<p>Conventional versus sumo deadlifts aside – even within one and the same style you still have some freedom of choice regarding foot position.</p>



<p>A rule of thumb is to <em>point your toes in the same direction that your knee travels</em>. This is not set in stone, however, and you still have some leeway to divert from this.</p>



<p><strong>In the conventional style</strong> you can choose to place your feet all the way together until your heels are touching. This will probably also require you to point your toes out a bit. More common and the best fit for most people, however, is to simply place the feet directly under your hip joints, with your toes pointing straight forward or only slightly out.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large is-resized"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Foot-position-in-the-deadlift-_-feet-forward.png?resize=700%2C474&#038;ssl=1" alt="Foot position in the deadlift _ feet forward" class="wp-image-505" style="width:715px;height:484px" width="700" height="474" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Foot-position-in-the-deadlift-_-feet-forward.png?resize=1024%2C694&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Foot-position-in-the-deadlift-_-feet-forward.png?resize=300%2C203&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Foot-position-in-the-deadlift-_-feet-forward.png?resize=768%2C521&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Foot-position-in-the-deadlift-_-feet-forward.png?w=1658&amp;ssl=1 1658w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Foot-position-in-the-deadlift-_-feet-forward.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Starting position with the feet pointing in the same direction as the knees – almost straight forward. The stance is narrow enough to allow the arms to be close to perpendicular to the floor, allowing for the highest starting position.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>By pointing your toes outward and tracking in the same direction with your knees, you will effectively &#8220;shorten&#8221; your femurs compared to keeping them pointing straight ahead, and maybe make it a bit easier to pass the bar past your knees.  </p>



<p>What you&#8217;ll want to avoid is a stance so wide that your knees push your arms out. You&#8217;ll want your arms to be perpendicular to the floor as seen from the front, as this will result in the shortest and strongest range of motion. With a wide grip, you&#8217;d have to lean over more to reach the bar, resulting in a weaker starting position.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="474" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Too-wide-foot-position-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=700%2C474&#038;ssl=1" alt="Too wide foot position in the deadlift" class="wp-image-507" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Too-wide-foot-position-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=1024%2C694&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Too-wide-foot-position-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=300%2C203&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Too-wide-foot-position-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=768%2C521&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Too-wide-foot-position-in-the-deadlift.png?w=1658&amp;ssl=1 1658w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Too-wide-foot-position-in-the-deadlift.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Here the stance is so wide that the knees push the elbows out. This forces you to lean forward, thus bringing you closer to the floor, and into a biomechanically weaker position. Avoid this if possible. It may be, however, that your thighs and abdomen are too big for a narrow stance, and thus forcing you to adopt a stance similar to this.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>It is a good idea to experiment a bit with different foot positions when you&#8217;re learning the deadlift, as your individual limb lengths will dictate what position suits you better. Lighter lifters with smaller thighs and bellies will find it easier to keep a narrow stance in the conventional deadlift, while super heavyweights and heavy strongmen often adopt a conventional deadlift style with a rather wide stance.</p>



<p><strong>In the sumo style</strong> you can choose to place your feet all the way out to the weight plates, or as close together as possible while still keeping your knees outside your arms – also known as <em>semi sumo</em> and popularized by legendary powerlifter Ed Coan.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="373" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Ed-Coan-Deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C373&#038;ssl=1" alt="Ed Coan Deadlift" class="wp-image-328" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Ed-Coan-Deadlift.jpg?w=750&amp;ssl=1 750w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Ed-Coan-Deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C160&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<p>With your femurs pointing more to the side in the sumo deadlift compared to the conventional, you&#8217;ll probably want to follow that same direction with your toes and point them more outward. A limitation here will be balance – the more you point your toes out, the more you&#8217;ll shorten your base of support in the sagittal plane, thus making it more difficult to maintain balance during the lift.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Arms</h3>



<p>The best visualization of your arms&#8217; roles in the deadlift is to act like ropes, attaching the bar to your shoulders. Preferrably, these should also be both long and straight ropes, as that will allow you to maximize your starting height in the lift.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="954" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=700%2C954&#038;ssl=1" alt="Arms in the deadlift" class="wp-image-509" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=751%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 751w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=220%2C300&amp;ssl=1 220w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift.png?resize=768%2C1048&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift.png?w=1656&amp;ssl=1 1656w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<p>The first few inches of a deadlift is the biomechanically weakest part of the lift, and the more you can extend your knees and hips from the start, the easier it will be to pass this point.<span id='easy-footnote-5-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-5-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/trainology/1/2/1_32/_article&quot;&gt;Journal of Trainology. 2012 Nov;1(2):32-35. Isometric Strength of Powerlifters in Key Positions of the Conventional Deadlift.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>5</sup></a></span>



<p>If you deadlift with your arms bent or excessively wide, you will have to lean over more, and thus end up in a weaker starting position.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="474" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift-comparison.jpg?resize=700%2C474&#038;ssl=1" alt="Arms in the deadlift comparison" class="wp-image-512" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift-comparison.jpg?resize=1024%2C693&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift-comparison.jpg?resize=300%2C203&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift-comparison.jpg?resize=768%2C520&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift-comparison.jpg?w=1660&amp;ssl=1 1660w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Arms-in-the-deadlift-comparison.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> Comparison between a straight arm vs bent arm (due to the knee pushing the arm out) starting position. In this example, the shoulders are 5% higher in the straight-arm position. </figcaption></figure>



<p>Another issue is injury risk – straight arms with relaxed biceps will likely minimize your risk of a bicep strain or even rupture while lifting heavy loads.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">How to Grip the Bar</h3>



<p>There are four common ways to grip the bar during deadlifts:</p>



<ol>
<li>Double overhand grip</li>



<li>Hook grip</li>



<li>Mixed grip</li>



<li>Lifting straps (not allowed in most powerlifting competitions)</li>
</ol>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading">Double Overhand Grip</h4>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="338" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-double-overhand-grip.jpg?resize=700%2C338&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift with double overhand grip" class="wp-image-529" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-double-overhand-grip.jpg?w=937&amp;ssl=1 937w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-double-overhand-grip.jpg?resize=300%2C145&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-double-overhand-grip.jpg?resize=768%2C370&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> Double overhand grip. </figcaption></figure></div>


<p>This is the standard, intuitive way to grab a barbell. You simply hold on to it with both palms facing your body (pronated), and the thumbs opposing the other fingers.</p>



<p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Comfortable and intuitive. The way you usually grab stuff.</li>



<li>Symmetrical for your arms and shoulders.</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Weak! The barbell will want to roll out of your grip. This grip technique is usually fine for beginners learning the deadlift form, but quickly becomes a greatly limiting factor for how much you can lift.</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading">Hook Grip</h4>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="340" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Hook-grip-deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C340&#038;ssl=1" alt="Hook grip deadlift" class="wp-image-517" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Hook-grip-deadlift.jpg?resize=1024%2C497&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Hook-grip-deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C145&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Hook-grip-deadlift.jpg?resize=768%2C372&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Hook-grip-deadlift.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Hook-grip-deadlift.jpg?w=2100&amp;ssl=1 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Hook grip as viewed from behind. First place your thumb alongside the bar, then lock it with your indexfinger. Viewed from the front, this grip will look just like a double overhand grip.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The hook grip is common in weightlifting and is an evolution of the double overhand grip. Despite them being very similar, the hook grip increases the weights you can lift by 20–30% or more. You still grab the bar with a double overhand grip, with the difference that you stick your thumb under your index finger (and maybe also your middle finger). The thumb will act like a wedge or a chock and hinder the bar from rolling out of your grip.</p>



<p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Much stronger than a regular overhand grip.</li>



<li>Symmetrical for your arms and shoulders.</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Painful! It gets better with time, but will still be more uncomfortable than the normal way of gripping a bar.</li>



<li>More wearing on your skin, limiting the volume you can do. This can be alleviated with lifting straps.</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading">Mixed Grip</h4>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="337" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-mixed-grip.jpg?resize=700%2C337&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift with mixed grip" class="wp-image-527" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-mixed-grip.jpg?w=938&amp;ssl=1 938w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-mixed-grip.jpg?resize=300%2C145&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-mixed-grip.jpg?resize=768%2C370&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Mixed grip.</figcaption></figure>



<p>The mixed grip is the most common grip technique in powerlifting. Here, you counter the barbell&#8217;s rotation by supinating one hand – that is, turning one palm facing away from you. Like the hook grip, this greatly increases the weight you can lift.</p>



<p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Much stronger than a regular overhand grip.</li>



<li>Not very painful or wearing on your skin (compared to hook grip)</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Asymmetrical for your arms and shoulders, which might transfer to an asymmetrical spine and hip position. It is unclear, however, if this actually is a problem. Probably not.</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading" id="liftingstraps">Lifting straps</h4>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="345" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-lifting-straps.jpg?resize=700%2C345&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift with lifting straps" class="wp-image-531" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-lifting-straps.jpg?w=902&amp;ssl=1 902w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-lifting-straps.jpg?resize=300%2C148&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-lifting-straps.jpg?resize=768%2C378&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Lifting straps.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>The last grip option worth mentioning here is the use of lifting straps. Lifting straps will remove any grip related limitations for your pulls, will spare your skin, and also enable you to pull with a symmetrical overhand grip. The downside is of course that you won&#8217;t reap the benefit of getting a stronger grip from your training. A good compromise for an avid deadlifter might be to use straps in about half of your deadlift training, if you feel that pain or damaged skin is holding you back.</p>



<p><strong>Pros:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Symmetrical for your arms and shoulders.</li>



<li>Very strong – grip won&#8217;t be a limiting factor.</li>



<li>Painless and spares your skin.</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>Cons:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>Won&#8217;t develop your grip strength.</li>



<li>Not allowed in most powerlifting competitions and thus might give false security.</li>



<li>One more thing to carry around in your gym bag.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Hip Position</h3>



<p>How high should your hips be in the starting position of a deadlift? Should you begin in more of a &#8220;squat&#8221; position, or something more along the lines of a stiff-legged deadlift?</p>



<p>The answer can be deduced if we make three assumptions:</p>



<ol>
<li>You&#8217;re going to keep your arms vertical as seen from the side (or very close to vertical) during the entire lift.</li>



<li>You&#8217;re going to keep the systems (your body + the bar = the system) center of mass roughly above your mid foot.</li>



<li>You&#8217;re going to keep your shins as close to the bar as possible while still allowing for number 1 and 2 above, as that will enable you to more effectively use both your knee and hip extensors.</li>
</ol>



<p>Number one above won&#8217;t be an issue – once the bar gets heavy enough, it&#8217;ll be positioned right below your shoulder joint, or at least very close to it.</p>



<p>But how do you find the position mentioned in point number two? Well, that&#8217;s the position in which you don&#8217;t lose your balance forward or backward during the pull – e.g. where you&#8217;ll automatically end up positioning the bar to keep your balance, without thinking about it. You can explore and reinforce this position by performing a pause deadlift, with the pause very low towards the floor.</p>



<p>Finally, keep your shins as close to the bar as possible while still doing number one and two above. For many of you, this will mean having your shins touching the bar.</p>



<p>These three points will have narrowed down your possible hip starting height quite a lot, but there is still some leeway regarding the exact height. The final adjustments of your hip position will depend on your personal strengths and weaknesses, especially in your back, hip and knee extensors.</p>



<ul>
<li><em>If you have </em>a strong back and strong hip extensors but weak knee extensors, you&#8217;ll be the strongest (and naturally drift towards) when you are a little bit more bent over and thus shifting more of the load towards your hip.</li>



<li><em>If you have </em>strong knee extensors but a weaker back or weak hip extensors, you&#8217;ll be the strongest (and naturally drift towards) when you have a more vertical torso and your shins/knees closer to the bar (or even past the bar, for taller lifters).</li>
</ul>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="312" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Different-hip-positions-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C312&#038;ssl=1" alt="Different hip positions in the deadlift" class="wp-image-534" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Different-hip-positions-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=1024%2C456&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Different-hip-positions-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C134&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Different-hip-positions-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=768%2C342&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Different-hip-positions-in-the-deadlift.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Different-hip-positions-in-the-deadlift.jpg?w=2100&amp;ssl=1 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Here I am trying to show different hip positions. The problem is: my anatomy doesn’t change between the pics, so only one of these three are really a viable option for me. The left pic with a high hip position is just fake posing: note the angle of the arm. As soon as I would try to lift a heavy weight that way, my arm would swing out to an angle perpendicular to the direction of gravity, and the moment arm from the weight to my hips would be very long and ineffective for heavy pulls. In the right pic with a low hip position on the other hand, the knees would be in the way of the bar. My personal starting position is the middle one. Just right for me.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Note that your ideal starting position probably is one that you already know and use. When we perform movements, we usually experience a bit of micro-variation. The movement simply doesn&#8217;t look exactly the same each rep, and if we by chance discover a slightly easier and more efficient way of performing a rep, we usually take notice – either consciously or subconsciously. That is why, as long as you&#8217;re not doing something fundamentally wrong – like keeping the bar way ahead of your shins – your current starting position is probably also your most effective one. At least right now.</p>



<p>As your body and musculature changes with continued training, so will your strengths and weaknesses change. That means that the most effective deadlift position in the beginning of your lifting career, might not be the same as your most effective lifting position when you are on your peak.</p>



<p>Do experiment with a slightly higher or lower hip position in the start – although my bet is that you&#8217;ll find that you&#8217;re either weaker with the new position, or will end up in your old position anyway when the load gets heavy enough.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Back Position in the Deadlift</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="396" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-flat-versus-round-back.jpg?resize=700%2C396&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift with flat versus round back" class="wp-image-556" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-flat-versus-round-back.jpg?resize=1024%2C579&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-flat-versus-round-back.jpg?resize=300%2C170&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-flat-versus-round-back.jpg?resize=768%2C434&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-flat-versus-round-back.jpg?w=1798&amp;ssl=1 1798w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Deadlift-with-flat-versus-round-back.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Flat (neutral) versus exaggeratedly rounded (flexed) back.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Should you deadlift with a flat or rounded back? Or to use more anatomically correct terms: <em>should you lift with your spine in a neutral or flexed position?</em></p>



<p><strong>The short answer</strong> is that we recommend you to deadlift with a neutral spine. An exception might be powerlifters or strongmen/-women who are fine with exchanging a slightly heavier lift with a <em>possibly</em> greater risk of injury.</p>



<p><strong>The long answer</strong> is that there are two aspects of this question to consider, namely:</p>



<p>How does the back position affect your &#8230;</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Performance?</strong></li>



<li><strong>Injury risk?</strong></li>
</ol>



<p>Let&#8217;s have a quick look at both in turn.</p>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading">Performance</h4>



<p>Why is it that as lifters (especially newer ones) pile on more and more weight, they tend to round their back more and more? Likely, because it&#8217;s <em>biomechanicaly efficient </em>– at least in the initial pull from the ground.</p>



<p>By rounding your back, you are essentially &#8220;shortening&#8221; your spine, and bringing your hips closer to the bar. The closer your hips are to the bar, the shorter the moment arm that they are working against gets, and the more weight you can lift with the same force from your hips. In the picture above where I show a neutral and exaggeratedly rounded spine, my hips are about 10% closer to the bar when I round my back, as opposed to keeping it flat. All other things equal, that means my hip extensors will suddenly let me lift 10% more weight.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="739" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Rounded-back-means-the-hip-is-closer-to-the-bar.jpg?resize=700%2C739&#038;ssl=1" alt="Rounded back means the hip is closer to the bar" class="wp-image-558" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Rounded-back-means-the-hip-is-closer-to-the-bar.jpg?w=896&amp;ssl=1 896w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Rounded-back-means-the-hip-is-closer-to-the-bar.jpg?resize=284%2C300&amp;ssl=1 284w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Rounded-back-means-the-hip-is-closer-to-the-bar.jpg?resize=768%2C811&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Rounding the back “shortens” your spine and brings your hips closer to the bar, thus decreasing the moment arm they have to work against.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Rounding your back in the initial portion of a deadlift is therefore not entirely a stupid thing to do, strategy-wise. It is, however, short-sighted.</p>



<p>The lift ain&#8217;t over until you have extended your knees, hips <em>and spine</em>, and flexing your spine in the beginning of the lift means that you will have to re-extend it later on. Something that might be easier said than done.</p>



<p>Some lifters are able to pull it off, and for them it might be a viable lifting strategy for peak performance.</p>



<p>Other lifters (such as myself) prefer to keep the back extended throughout the whole lift. It makes the beginning of the lift harder, but the upside is that if you clear the bar of the first few inches of the ground, you typically got it.</p>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading">Injury Risk</h4>



<p>This is probably the most debated aspect of the back position in the deadlift. And just like many other aspects of training were there is alot of debate, the reason that there even is a debate in the first place is either because we don&#8217;t have definitive answers, or because there isn&#8217;t much of a difference between the two cases – or both.</p>



<p>Is one lifting style more prone to spinal injury than the other?</p>



<p>The best answer we have thus far is: <em>We don&#8217;t know.</em></p>



<p>On the one hand, lifting with a flexed back increases the load on passive structures in your spine, such as your vertebraes or intervertebral discs.<span id='easy-footnote-6-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-6-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1566169/&quot;&gt;Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 1992 Mar;17(3):327-34. Erector spinae activation and movement dynamics about the lumbar spine in lordotic and kyphotic squat-lifting.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>6</sup></a></span> On the other hand, we know that even passive structures like the intervertebral discs are living tissue that adapts to the challenges we impose on it.<span id='easy-footnote-7-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-7-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28422125&quot;&gt;Sci Rep. 2017 Apr 19;7:45975. doi: 10.1038/srep45975. Running exercise strengthens the intervertebral disc.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>7</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-8-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-8-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3207351/&quot;&gt;Eur Spine J. 2011 Nov; 20(11): 1796–1812. The effects of dynamic loading on the intervertebral disc.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>8</sup></a></span> That means that as you keep logging hours in the gym and gaining strength and muscle, your spine will get more resilient.</p>



<p>Neither does a neutral spine seem to offer protection against disc herniations or damage to vertebral endplates.<span id='easy-footnote-9-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-9-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20838275&quot;&gt;Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2010 Oct 1;35(21):1897-908. doi: 10.1097/BRS.0b013e3181d9b69e. ISSLS prize winner: how loading rate influences disc failure mechanics: a microstructural assessment of internal disruption.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>9</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-10-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-10-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24503692&quot;&gt;Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2014 Jun 1;39(13):1018-28. doi: 10.1097/BRS.0000000000000262. How healthy discs herniate: a biomechanical and microstructural study investigating the combined effects of compression rate and flexion.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>10</sup></a></span>



<h4 class="wp-block-heading">So – Should You Deadlift With a Neutral or Flexed Spine?</h4>



<p>Our practical, general recommendation is this:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Strive for neutral. </strong>Strive to lift with a neutral back in all of your training and in competition. At the very least, this will raise the limit for what weight you can pull before your spine flexes.</li>



<li><strong>Don&#8217;t be greedy.</strong> Generally avoid lifting with a flexed back in your training – if you cannot maintain a neutral spine, lower the weight or perform less reps per set.</li>



<li><strong>Save it for the competition?</strong> Lifting with a flexed spine <em>might</em> increase your risk of injury – it also might not. An occasional lift with a flexed spine at competition is <em>probably </em>fine – most powerlifting injuries seem to creep up over time, rather than being acute.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Bracing</h3>



<p>Bracing refers to the act of keeping your core rigid during a lift. Your spine is made up of 33 vertebrae, of which the first 24 can move to a degree in any direction. Without your core muscles keeping your spine rigid, you wouldn&#8217;t be able to deadlift.</p>



<p>The core musculature is made up of at least a dozen different muscles, both superficial (like your abs and spinal erectors) and deep (like your diaphragm and pelvic floor). The core muscles also surround your spine on all sides: the four abdominals (rectus abdominis, transversus abdominis, and the internal and external obliques) on the front and sides, and the large muscle group erector spinae on the back, are some of the larger ones.</p>



<div class="wp-block-columns has-2-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-3 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow"><div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="462" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Transversus-abdominis-deadlift.png?resize=462%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Transversus abdominis deadlift" class="wp-image-388" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Transversus-abdominis-deadlift.png?w=462&amp;ssl=1 462w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Transversus-abdominis-deadlift.png?resize=198%2C300&amp;ssl=1 198w" sizes="(max-width: 462px) 100vw, 462px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Transversus abdominis is the deepest of the four abdominal muscles, located beneath the internal and external obliques, and rectus abdominis.</figcaption></figure></div></div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="543" height="1024" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/spinal-muscles-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=543%2C1024&#038;ssl=1" alt="spinal muscles in the deadlift" class="wp-image-389" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/spinal-muscles-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=543%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 543w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/spinal-muscles-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=159%2C300&amp;ssl=1 159w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/spinal-muscles-in-the-deadlift.jpg?w=625&amp;ssl=1 625w" sizes="(max-width: 543px) 100vw, 543px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">The multifidus and erector spinae run along your spine, all the way from your sacrum up to the cervical spine, and are primarly responsible for exending your spine during deadlifts.</figcaption></figure>
</div>
</div>



<p>Bracing a dozen or more core muscles apropriately for different lifting tasks requires great intermuscular coordination, and is generally best left to the body to figure out on it&#8217;s own through repeated practice of the specific lift.</p>



<p>You can, however, give the core some help on the way. To do this, start by taking a deep breath, about 80% of maximum. Then, it&#8217;s time to tense up your core muscles. My favourite way of teaching this is to stick your fingers into your sides, slightly above your hip bones. Then push your fingers out by tensing your core muscles. Practice this until you can do it without using your fingers, and then start doing it when you are deadlifting.</p>



<p>Realize that the core will have to brace in different ways depending on if you&#8217;re sitting comfortably in your chair and sticking your fingers into your sides, or if you&#8217;re deadlifting 400 pounds (or more), so while this manual bracing might help a bit in the beginning, you will still have to learn bracing by actually lifting a bar.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Building Tension</h3>



<p>Deadlifts are <em>hard</em>. And if you&#8217;re going to pull one off, you&#8217;d better be too.</p>



<p>Effective deadlifting requires efficient force transfer. The force must be transferred from the bar, via your grip, arms and shoulders, through your torso down to your hips, and finally down via your legs and feet to the floor. </p>



<p>A key to effective force transfer is <em>stiffness</em>, and this ties in with the previous section on bracing. Your arms are going to be straight and stiff like ropes, and won&#8217;t have much give. Your legs are pretty much just straight bones connected by some of the prime movers, and stiffness won&#8217;t be an issue here either. The core however, with it&#8217;s pelvis connected to the spine with it&#8217;s 33 vertebrae is in great need of stabilization – especially in the conventional deadlift since it places greater demands on your low back. A braced and stiff core will be essential for effective force transfer, which is why it requires some special attention.</p>



<p>Before you push the pedal to the metal and revv up those strong prime movers in your back, hip and knee extensors, you&#8217;d better take a moment to make sure your core is good to go, and this is done by <em>building tension</em>. It is simply the act of preparing your body of what is about to come.</p>



<p>Now, this can be done in a few different ways, where probably the most common are:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Consciously tensing your body.</strong> You contract the core muscles like we covered earlier, you engage your lats by driving the bar into your shins, and you grab the bar excessively hard to get an irradiation effect where the tonus of other muscles increase. This way you&#8217;ll build up tension throughout your body in a pretty conscious way.</li>



<li><strong>Gradually pushing down the gas pedal.</strong> The other way to go about it is by gradually exerting more and more force into the bar, perhaps over 1–3 seconds before the bar finally breaks the ground, as to give your body a chance to develop the right tension in the right places. This is more of a subconscious route of building tension, which might have the prerequisite of a bit experience with deadlifts.</li>



<li>And of course, you might also <strong>combine both </strong>of the two tactics above into your own flavour of building tension.</li>
</ul>



<p>The opposite of this might be the &#8220;dip, grip, and rip&#8221;-technique, which is performed quickly and is pretty self-explanatory. Realize that a true <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>deadlift will <em>never</em> move quickly, but that doesn&#8217;t mean that you can&#8217;t initiate the pull quickly. This deadlift technique, quickly dipping down, grabbing the bar, and ripping it off the floor is also a viable one, but it comes with two additional conditions:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Higher requisite of motor skill</strong>. You&#8217;ll still have to tense all the right muscles, but now you have less time to do it. That means you better have a very well ingrained groove for your deadlift motor pattern.</li>



<li><strong>Higher risk.</strong> Even if you are a very experienced deadlifter and are used to this style of pulling, you will still take a larger risk of mis-timing the lifting sequence compared to if you&#8217;d take your time more with it.</li>
</ul>



<p>Our general recommendation is to be a bit more patient in the last moments before the pull, and take your time gradually building up tension before the bar breaks the floor.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Lift-Off</h3>



<p>As previously mentioned, <a href="https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/trainology/1/2/1_32/_article">the starting position is generally your biomechanically weakest point in a deadlift</a>. However, this does not mean that the beginning of a deadlift is where most lifters get stuck and fail their lift, but more on that in the section on the lock-out. </p>



<p>Even if it&#8217;s not your sticking point, the beginning is still very important and might still make or break your lift depending on:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>How much energy </strong>you will be wasting when you&#8217;re trying to get through it, and</li>



<li><strong>What position you are in</strong> when you clear the lift-off.</li>
</ol>



<p>Since the starting position is generally the biomechanical weak spot, this is where, if you watch the deadlifting event in a powerlifting competition, you might see some funny stuff going on in the moments just before, during or after the bar breaks off the floor.</p>



<p>Or, you might see it in yourself: when the weight gets heavy enough and you begin to pull, you might start shifting around your body position. Perhaps you hadn&#8217;t nailed the right hip position or trunk angle, and as you begin exerting force into the bar your body naturally shifts to a stronger (or perceived stronger) position. Perhaps you are not strong enough to break the bar off the floor without rounding your back and thus decreasing the moment arms of your prime movers by bringing the bar closer to their respective joints.</p>



<p>The lift-off is really about nailing down two things:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Knowing</strong> your strongest pulling technique, and &#8230;</li>



<li><strong>Using and maintaining</strong> your strongest pulling technique.</li>
</ol>



<p>Your own strongest pulling technique will entail things like: how you distribute work between hip and knee extensors, what sequence and speed you will extend different joints in, and whether or not you are going to pull with a rounded or straight back.</p>



<p>While I on the one hand believe that your body is smart, and sometimes better left to figure out things on it&#8217;s own, this is not neccessarily one of those cases. Reason being, the start is a point where you might need to lift a little counter-intuitively.</p>



<p>One such example is when the butt shoots upward before the bar has barely begun to move. What has happened is that the lifter has effectively dumped over most if not all work from the quadriceps to the back and hip extensors. Now, this <em>might</em> be because the lifter simply is relatively much stronger in their posterior chain, and this deadlift technique just makes use of that strength. But it might also be the case that the lifter just doesn&#8217;t know how the start of a deadlift might feel, and is simply not patient enough for the quads and the hip extensors to hit their coordination and make the (maybe: more efficient) pull.</p>



<p>While the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squat </a>typically involves a simultaneous extension of hips and knees, the deadlift is more segmented into three distinct phases:</p>



<ol>
<li>Mostly knee extension</li>



<li>Mostly hip extension</li>



<li>Simultaneous knee and hip extension until lock-out</li>
</ol>



<p>The graphs below illustrate this. They&#8217;re averages from an analysis of 25 competing powerlifters heaviest successful attempt at a competition, and show the ratio of knee extension (y-axis) to hip extension (x-axis). Notice the difference between the two lifts, and the segmented look of the deadlift.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="368" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Ratio-of-hip-and-knee-extension-in-the-squat.jpg?resize=700%2C368&#038;ssl=1" alt="Ratio of hip and knee extension in the squat" class="wp-image-419" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Ratio-of-hip-and-knee-extension-in-the-squat.jpg?w=747&amp;ssl=1 747w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Ratio-of-hip-and-knee-extension-in-the-squat.jpg?resize=300%2C158&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> Ratio of hip and knee extension in the&nbsp;<strong>squat</strong>. (<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19910816">Hales, 2009</a>) </figcaption></figure></div>

<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="370" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Ratio-of-hip-and-knee-extension-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C370&#038;ssl=1" alt="Ratio of hip and knee extension in the deadlift" class="wp-image-420" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Ratio-of-hip-and-knee-extension-in-the-deadlift.jpg?w=747&amp;ssl=1 747w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Ratio-of-hip-and-knee-extension-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C159&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> Ratio of hip and knee extension in the&nbsp;<strong>deadlift</strong>. Notice how it begins with mostly knee extension, shifts to mostly hip extension, and then shifts back again. (<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19910816">Hales, 2009</a>) </figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Another positional shift that might happen during the lift-off is the (potentially) short-sighted &#8220;loan&#8221; that a lifter takes from the lock-out to pay the initial pull when they round their back. Yes, the first phase of the lift becomes easier due to shorter moment arms, but the lock-out becomes harder when you have to re-extend those facet joints between the vertebraes.</p>



<p>You will simply have to experiment to find out for yourself:</p>



<ul>
<li>Are you stronger when you let your butt shoot up in the start, or when your patiently push with your legs until the bar finally gives?</li>



<li>Are you stronger when you deadlift with a straight back during the whole lift, or when you initally round your back but re-extend it during the lock-out?</li>
</ul>



<p>Your individual optimal deadlift technique will vary, but if we yet again shall revert to generalizations, we believe that most lifters will eventually have their greatest performances when they patiently let their quadriceps contribute to the lift, resulting in a pronounced knee extension in the start, as well as pulling with a more or less straight back through the first phase of the lift, thereby ridding themselves the task of re-extending their spine.</p>



<p>So how do you go about accomplishing this? Both depend on grooving the right neuromuscular motor patterns, which in plain English means <em>train a lot</em>. With the desired technique. With progressively heavier weights, as you get increasingly good at maintaining your technique with heavier weights.</p>



<p>To train this, you will be needing some kind of feedback to discern whether you&#8217;re doing it right or wrong:</p>



<ul>
<li>A coach/friend/enemy who knows what to look for might give you feedback after a set or even after every rep.</li>



<li>You could set up your phone to record your lift, and review the film in between your sets.</li>
</ul>



<p>Besides getting feedback, there are some cues that generally are helpful to teach these aspects of the deadlift technique:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong><em>Push the floor away</em></strong>, or <strong><em>pull the sword out of the rock</em>.</strong> Meaning, instead of pulling the barbell <em>up</em>, you focus on pushing the floor away, or down. The King Arthur-analogy still entails pulling something up, but there&#8217;s something about it that still can make the right technique and &#8220;feeling&#8221; just <em>click</em>.</li>



<li><strong><em>Chest up</em>.</strong> Maybe not as vivid a visualization, but this cue is one of the best to help a lifter maintain a more straight back.</li>
</ul>



<p>Now we&#8217;ve covered the initial phase of the deadlift, which includes the weakest point of the lift. </p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">The Lock-Out (and The Sticking Point)</h3>



<p>So you&#8217;ve cleared the first part of the lift. While biomechanically the weakest part, that is not where the sticking point generally is. No, the most common sticking point in the deadlift is when you are pretty close to having the weight locked out, when your thighs are at about a 57± 5 degree angle relative to the floor.<span id='easy-footnote-11-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-11-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19910816&quot;&gt;J Strength Cond Res. 2009 Dec;23(9):2574-80. Kinematic analysis of the powerlifting style squat and the conventional deadlift during competition: is there a cross-over effect between lifts?&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>11</sup></a></span>



<p>Here&#8217;s a chart showing the heaviest successful deadlift attempt from a powerlifting competition. The sticking point is defined as the point where the bar begins to accelerate again after having slowed down somewhere in the middle of the lift, and it is in this position that a lifters thigh angle generally is around 57 degrees (with just a small 5 degree standard deviation). The sticking point is marked with &#8220;P3&#8221;.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="345" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Vertical-bar-velocity-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=700%2C345&#038;ssl=1" alt="Vertical bar velocity in the deadlift" class="wp-image-424" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Vertical-bar-velocity-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=1024%2C504&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Vertical-bar-velocity-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=300%2C148&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Vertical-bar-velocity-in-the-deadlift.jpg?resize=768%2C378&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Vertical-bar-velocity-in-the-deadlift.jpg?w=1167&amp;ssl=1 1167w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> Vertical bar velocity in the heaviest successful deadlift attempts in competition. The sticking point is marked as P3, and is where the bar slows during the lift, and then accelerates again. (<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19910816">Hales, 2009</a>) </figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Note that the sticking point won&#8217;t necessarily be where you fail an attempt that is too heavy for you:</p>



<ul>
<li>If you try to lift a weight that way too heavy for you, it won&#8217;t budge from the floor.</li>



<li>If you try to lift a weight that is a little bit too heavy (perhaps 2+%), it will get stuck during the first few inches off the floor.</li>



<li>If you try to lift a weight that is <em>just</em> too heavy (perhaps &lt;1%), it will get stuck when the bar slows down mid-lift – in the sticking point.</li>
</ul>



<p>But if the starting position is the biomechanially weakest part of a deadlift (tested on powerlifters), why do powerlifters have their sticking point much later in the lift, at a 57 degree thigh angle?</p>



<p>There might be several contributing factors, but the primary answer might well turn out to be <em>energy expenditure</em>. Short, forceful bursts of work depends primarily on free <em>adenosine triphosphate</em> (ATP) and <em>creatine phosphate</em> (PCr). ATP is the energy used for muscle contractions, and PCr is the quickest way of regenerating ATP in muscle. Your stores of ATP lasts only for ~2 seconds of work at maximum force and your strength starts to decline shortly after, even if your stores of PCr aids in maintaining it. Peak power output is reached after about ~3 seconds of maximal work, and after 6 seconds might be only 90% of that.<span id='easy-footnote-12-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-12-8652' title='Maughan &amp;amp; Gleeson, The Biochemical Basis of Sports Performance, 2nd edition. 2010.'><sup>12</sup></a></span>



<p>A deadlift that is close to your max will always move slowly, but there is a disproportionate decrease in speed when you increase the load with the last few percentages from 97–98% of your max, to 100%. A deadlift that is truly 100% of your capacity (as in: if a fly lands on the bar during the lift you would fail) might very well take 7–8 seconds from start to finish, which means you will have burned almost all of your highest octane fuel by the time you are at your sticking point.</p>



<p>Now, given that you <em>are</em> strong enough to complete the lift, the lock-out part of a deadlift is actually pretty simple (not the same as easy). All you have to do is: extend your knees, hips and back, and keep your shoulder back for the lift to be considered completed. </p>



<p>If there is any need for a cue for this, it might be to simply <strong>drive your hips forward</strong>, kind of like a hip thrust. If you&#8217;re having troubles extending your spine in the top or having &#8220;soft knees&#8221; (not fully extended), a helpful visualization might be to imagine a chain attached to the top of your head, pulling you upwards.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="643" height="520" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/deadlift-lock-out.jpg?resize=643%2C520&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift lock out" class="wp-image-1292" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/deadlift-lock-out.jpg?w=643&amp;ssl=1 643w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/deadlift-lock-out.jpg?resize=300%2C243&amp;ssl=1 300w" sizes="(max-width: 643px) 100vw, 643px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Yours truly, locking out a deadlift, many years ago.</figcaption></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Setting the Bar Down</h3>



<p>You did it! You&#8217;ve locked out the bar and fully extended your body to an upright position. If you are competing, you will have to wait for the referee to give you a &#8220;<em>Down!</em>&#8220;-command, but otherwise it is time to set the bar down.</p>



<p>There are two things to cover here:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>How to </strong>set the bar down safely.</li>



<li><strong>Is there a strength advantage </strong>to setting the bar down slowly in your training?</li>
</ul>



<p>The technique of setting down the bar is pretty straightforward – you simply backtrack your steps from the pull, even though we compress it slightly into two distinct phases:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Hip hinge.</strong> Initiate the eccentric by pushing your butt back and leaning your torso forward. The knees bend, but not as fast as your hip. Lower the bar along your legs like this until you&#8217;ve cleared the knees.</li>



<li><strong>Knee bend</strong>. When the bar has cleared your knees, you are probably leaning as far forward as you&#8217;re going to get. At this point you take out the rest of the movement with your knees, and simply bend them until the bar touches the ground.</li>
</ol>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Greater Gains from a Controlled Eccentric?</h3>



<p>The tricky part of a deadlift is the way up – the <em>concentric </em>phase. That is what you compete with in powerlifting, and the way down (the <em>eccentric </em>phase) is mostly a formality, where the only rule is to lower the bar with control and maintaining your grip on it until it rests on the floor.</p>



<p>Most powerlifters set the bar down pretty much as quickly as they can, both in training and competition. The are probably several reasons for this, among them being that eccentrics are uncomfortable and setting the bar down with a load bang looks and sounds pretty badass (hey, it does), but the main reason cited is <em><strong>specificity</strong>.</em></p>



<p>The principle of specificity has proven itself to reign supreme in the realm of all sports, and in deadlifts you compete in the concentric – not eccentric – phase. Besides, if you conserve your energy on the way down, won&#8217;t you be able to get in a few more good concentric reps before you&#8217;re worn out for the day?</p>



<p>That might be the case.</p>



<p>It might also be short-sighted.</p>



<p>Several studies has compared the <em>concentric</em> strength gains from training protocols where you either perform concentric reps only or concentric+eccentric (that is, normal training) reps, and found that concentric+eccentric training yields greater concentric strength gains – <em>even if you perform twice as many concentric reps to volume match the two training protocols.</em><span id='easy-footnote-13-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-13-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2275403&quot;&gt;Acta Physiol Scand. 1990 Sep;140(1):31-9. Effects of eccentric and concentric muscle actions in resistance training.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>13</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-14-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-14-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287194952_The_effects_of_concentriceccentric_training_versus_concentric_only_training_on_peak_power_and_functional_muscle_performance&quot;&gt;2015 ASCA International Conference on Applied Strength and Conditioning. The effects of concentric/eccentric training versus concentric only training on peak power and functional muscle performance.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>14</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-15-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-15-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2269843/&quot;&gt;J Physiol. 2000 Apr 1; 524(Pt 1): 293–304. Changes in muscle strength, muscle fibre size and myofibrillar gene expression after immobilization and retraining in humans.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>15</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-16-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-16-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12688453&quot;&gt;Aviat Space Environ Med. 2003 Apr;74(4):342-7. Strength gains following different combined concentric and eccentric exercise regimens.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>16</sup></a></span>



<p><strong>What might this mean for your deadlift training?</strong> That even if you perform twice as many reps where you set the bar down quickly (without really braking it&#8217;s fall), you&#8217;re still not getting as good gains as if you were to really slow down the bar, and lower it under, say, at least two seconds.</p>



<p>Thus, a little bit more work and discomfort invested in your deadlift training in the shape of more prolonged eccentrics might pay good dividends. And I&#8217;ve personally found that it doesn&#8217;t really decrease the amount of good sets and reps I do in my training, so the excuse that <em>&#8220;I save my energy to perform more concentric reps&#8221;</em> not only seems wrong (in the sense that concentric+eccentric training yiels better strength gains even if you double the amount of reps in the concentric-only training), it&#8217;s also not what happens in real life.</p>



<p>A good guideline if you&#8217;d like to try accentuating the eccentric phase in deadlifts is to simply play into the hands of Planet Fitness and the like, and try to set the bar down without making a noise. The irony is beautiful.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="467" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?resize=700%2C467&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift technique" class="wp-image-8552" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?resize=1024%2C683&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?resize=300%2C200&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?resize=768%2C512&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?resize=1536%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?resize=2048%2C1366&amp;ssl=1 2048w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-technique.jpg?w=2100&amp;ssl=1 2100w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How to Become Stronger in the Deadlift</h2>



<p>So you&#8217;ve decided you want to become stronger in the deadlift. How do you go about it?</p>



<p>The weight you can lift in the deadlift is determined by the amount of force you can produce in your muscles (primarily the extensors of the hip, knee, and back) and transfer into the bar. To deadlift more weight, you must generate more force into the bar.</p>



<p>If you strip it down to the essentials, there are three different domains in which you can improve in order to accomplish this, and those are:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Muscle &amp; tendon.</strong> This is your hardware. A bigger muscle produces more force, and a stiffer tendon transfers that force into your bones more efficiently. Skeletal muscle mass is strongly correlated (~r=0.85) with deadlift performance.</li>
</ol>



<p>In training for sports, the principle of specificity reigns supreme. It means that if you want to become better at deadlifting, then you&#8217;d better train the deadlift to some extent. It does not, however, apply equally to all three points in the list above. Rather, the requirement for specificity increases with each point above.</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>To build bigger muscles</strong>, you simply have to train them in any reasonable way. Yes, strength gains can be quite specific in terms of vectors, but if you build bigger and stronger glutes using hip thrusts (for example), you will still have a bigger and stronger hip extensor when you go back to the deadlift.</li>



<li><strong>Tendons</strong> increase in stiffness from all heavy training, and the degree of specificity in terms of exercise choice is quite low here as well.</li>



<li><strong>Improvements in neuromuscular efficiency </strong>and especially <strong>technique</strong> require more specificity, and you will actually have to practice the lift in which you want to improve. Preferrably at pretty heavy loads.</li>
</ul>



<p>This means that you can roughly divide your deadlift training into two distinct goals:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Building bigger and stronger muscles.</strong></li>



<li><strong>Specific deadlift practice.</strong></li>
</ol>



<p>Now, deadlifting in and of itself of course works all the relevant muscles for deadlifting, but limiting yourself to <em>only </em>deadlifts might limit the amount of productive muscle-building training that you could do, and thus hamper your strength gains – especially in the long term, where muscle mass plays a greater role.<span id='easy-footnote-17-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-17-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/453338&quot;&gt;Am J Phys Med. 1979 Jun;58(3):115-30. Neural factors versus hypertrophy in the time course of muscle strength gain.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>17</sup></a></span>


<div class="wp-block-image">
