<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1968" height="1932" src="https://i2.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?fit=1024%2C1005&amp;ssl=1" alt="Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass" class="wp-image-2830" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?w=1968&amp;ssl=1 1968w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?resize=300%2C295&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?resize=1024%2C1005&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?resize=768%2C754&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?resize=1536%2C1508&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Correlation-between-deadlift-1RM-and-fat-free-mass.jpg?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> Relationship between deadlift <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>and fat-free mass in 20 elite powerlifters. (<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11990746">Brechue, 2002</a>) </figcaption></figure></div>


<p>More conducive to long-term strength gains might be to keep a portion of specific deadlift practice in your training, and then add in hypertrophy work for the major muscles worked in the deadlift:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Knee extensors:</strong> <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/quad-muscles-exercises-workout/">Quadriceps</a></li>



<li><strong>Hip extensors:</strong> <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">Glutes</a>, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hamstring-muscles-exercises-workout/">hamstrings</a>, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hip-adductor-muscles-exercises-workout/">adductors</a></li>



<li><strong>Back extensors:</strong> <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-back-muscles-exercises-workout/">Lower back</a></li>
</ul>



<p>With this in mind, let&#8217;s see how this manifests itself in different training variables.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Training Volume for the Deadlift</h3>



<p>The optimal <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/training-volume/">training volume</a> varies widely between individuals and is dependent on several factors, such as:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Training status.</strong> The more accustomed you are to training, the more volume you can handle and likely need.</li>



<li><strong>Age.</strong> Young to middle-aged adults likely recover easier than elderly ones.</li>



<li><strong>Nutrition.</strong> Calories and protein are the currencies of adaption. The more you put in, the more you can spend.</li>



<li><strong>Recovery.</strong> Good sleep and low stress increase your ability to endure and adapt to the training.</li>
</ul>



<p>The relationship between strength gains and training volume follows an inverted U-shape, where both too little and too much training leads to inferior gains.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1332" height="846" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Optimal-training-volume.jpg?fit=1024%2C650&amp;ssl=1" alt="Optimal training volume" class="wp-image-2832" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Optimal-training-volume.jpg?w=1332&amp;ssl=1 1332w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Optimal-training-volume.jpg?resize=300%2C191&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Optimal-training-volume.jpg?resize=1024%2C650&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Optimal-training-volume.jpg?resize=768%2C488&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"> You’ll neither want to train too little nor too much for optimal gains. But if you have to choose, erring on the side of too little will at least spare you time and decrease your injury risk. </figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Research into resistance training volume is carried out primarily on beginners or intermediate trainees. Generally, a low weekly set volume (less than 5 sets/week) is good, but a high volume (more than 10 sets/week) yields slightly better strength gains in this population.<span id='easy-footnote-18-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-18-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28755103&quot;&gt;Sports Med. 2017 Dec;47(12):2585-2601. doi: 10.1007/s40279-017-0762-7. The Effect of Weekly Set Volume on Strength Gain: A Meta-Analysis.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>18</sup></a></span>



<p>The upper limit of productive training volume is less researched, but might be in the vicinity of 15 sets to failure per week for new or intermediate lifters.<span id='easy-footnote-19-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-19-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2468867319300513&quot;&gt;Current Opinion in Physiology. Available online 17 April 2019. Training for Strength and Hypertrophy: An Evidence-based Approach.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>19</sup></a></span>



<p>Stopping your sets a few reps short of failure will likely increase the number of sets you can perform and recover properly from.<span id='easy-footnote-20-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-20-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28965198&quot;&gt;Eur J Appl Physiol. 2017 Dec;117(12):2387-2399. doi: 10.1007/s00421-017-3725-7. Epub 2017 Sep 30. Time course of recovery following resistance training leading or not to failure.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>20</sup></a></span> Training to failure is not necessary for optimal strength gains, and might even be counter-productive, especially in the context of complex, multi-joint exercises like the deadlift.<span id='easy-footnote-21-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-21-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26666744&quot;&gt;Sports Med. 2016 Apr;46(4):487-502. doi: 10.1007/s40279-015-0451-3. Effect of Training Leading to Repetition Failure on Muscular Strength: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>21</sup></a></span>



<p>Below are some general volume recommendations in terms of working sets of deadlifts. They are based partly on the research litterature and partly on our own experience of training and powerlifting.</p>



<p>The recommendations pertain to working sets. That is sets that are challenging but are generally not performed to failure but leaving 1–2 reps in the tank. </p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Low volume, 3–5 sets per week:</strong> This is a suitable volume for the beginner lifter that is simultaneously getting used to squatting maybe 1–2 times a week and thus is acclimatizing to a lot of new stress. It might also be suitable for the intermediate lifter, either tapering or taking a minimalistic approach to deadlifting while perhaps focusing on hypertrophy work for the deadlifting musculature.</li>



<li><strong>Medium volume, 6–13 sets per week:</strong> The goldilocks zone, and probably a nice target volume for most people in the intermediate stage. Recovery demands will be quite low if this is the only training you do for the lower body, but if you add in <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squats </a>and deadlift accessory training, the total volume will place quite high demands on your recovery. This might be a suitable volume for an advanced lifter who is tapering.</li>



<li>High volume, 14–20 sets per week: For the intermediate lifter who is stuck on a plateau and wants his or her deadlift to ascend to the next level, or for the advanced lifter. Recovery demands are high, especially if this is coupled with <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squat </a>training and accessory work. Most will have to gradually increase their volume to this level over a long time, and some lifters might find it too much for them, and that medium volume works better.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Training Volume for Muscles Used in the Deadlift</h3>



<p>For optimal deadlift gains, you will probably want to train the prime mover muscles more than you can do if you&#8217;d only use deadlifts. By varying your exercises, you can probably lower the risk of over-use injuries.</p>



<p>A recent meta-analysis found that 9+ sets per muscle per week resulted in hypertrophy gains of 8.0% over a period of 12 weeks, compared with 5.9% for less than 9 sets per week.<span id='easy-footnote-22-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-22-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27433992&quot;&gt;J Sports Sci. 2017 Jun;35(11):1073-1082. doi: 10.1080/02640414.2016.1210197. Epub 2016 Jul 19. Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass: A systematic review and meta-analysis.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>22</sup></a></span> However, most studies in the meta-analysis (12 out of 14) were conducted on previously untrained participants, and research on well-trained lifters is lacking. In most studies the sets were also performed to failure; stopping the sets short of failure likely increases the volume you can do and recover from.</p>



<p>If your deadlift volume is along the lines of medium (6–13 sets/week) or even high volume (14–20 sets/week), then you are already training all the prime movers reasonably well. Add in <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squat </a>training at least once a week, and you have a solid foundation of training for all the prime mover muscles.</p>



<p>However, both <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squats </a>and deadlifts can be quite strenuous, and there might be room for some &#8220;easier&#8221; exercises for a small additional increase in gains. Read more about this in the section &#8220;Assistance Exercises&#8221;.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Training Frequency for the Deadlift</h3>



<p>In meta-analyses conducted on mostly (~90%) untrained populations, resistance training frequency doesn&#8217;t seem to impact gains in strength or hypertrophy much as long as the total training volume is the same.<span id='easy-footnote-23-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-23-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29470825&quot;&gt;Sports Med. 2018 May;48(5):1207-1220. doi: 10.1007/s40279-018-0872-x. Effect of Resistance Training Frequency on Gains in Muscular Strength: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>23</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-24-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-24-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27102172&quot;&gt;Sports Med. 2016 Nov;46(11):1689-1697. doi: 10.1007/s40279-016-0543-8. Effects of Resistance Training Frequency on Measures of Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>24</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-25-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-25-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30236847&quot;&gt;J Sci Med Sport. 2019 Mar;22(3):361-370. doi: 10.1016/j.jsams.2018.09.223. Epub 2018 Sep 13. Resistance training frequency and skeletal muscle hypertrophy: A review of available evidence.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>25</sup></a></span> </p>



<p>However, the total training volume that you can positively adapt to is likely higher with a higher training frequency, as you&#8217;ll hit the maximum number of sets that can be productively performed in a session, before you&#8217;ll hit the maximum number of sets that can be productively performed in a whole week.</p>



<p>Therefore, training frequency might be an important mediator for training volume. Do you want to train a lot? Well, sooner or later you&#8217;ll have to distribute the training on more days, before your current workouts swell beyond the scope of what is productive to do in one session.</p>



<p>A rough limit on the number of work sets of deadlifts in a single session might be somewhere in the neighbourhood of 10 sets for an experienced lifter, but you might want to split the training volume to two sessions earlier than that, perhaps at 8 work sets.</p>



<p>Here&#8217;s how you might distribute the aforementioned volume recommendations on different training frequencies:</p>



<ul>
<li>Low volume, 3–5 sets per week: 1 session per week.</li>



<li>Medium volume, 6–13 sets per week: 1–2 sessions per week.</li>



<li>High volume, 14–20 sets per week: 2–3 sessions per week.</li>
</ul>



<p>The deadlift is widely considered to require longer rest between sessions compared to the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squat </a>or <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bench-press/">bench press</a>. This, however, is not reflected in studies examining fatigue after strenuous training sessions for the three lifts.<span id='easy-footnote-26-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-26-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30779596&quot;&gt;Appl Physiol Nutr Metab. 2019 Feb 19. doi: 10.1139/apnm-2019-0004. Time Course of Recovery is Similar for the Back Squat, Bench Press, and Deadlift in Well-Trained Males.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>26</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-27-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-27-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28704311&quot;&gt;J Strength Cond Res. 2017 Jul 12. doi: 10.1519/JSC.0000000000002140. Acute neuromuscular and endocrine responses to two different compound exercises: squat versus deadlift.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>27</sup></a></span>



<p>A survey of 104 mid-level Swedish powerlifters revealed that they, on average, train deadlifts 1.6 ± 0.8 times per week, but train <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squats </a>2.2 ± 1.0 times per week.<span id='easy-footnote-28-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-28-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5954586/&quot;&gt;Orthop J Sports Med. 2018 May; 6(5): 2325967118771016. Prevalence and Consequences of Injuries in Powerlifting: A Cross-sectional Study.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>28</sup></a></span>



<p>About 1–2 deadlift sessions per week is not a bad starting point for someone who also trains squats or similar lower-body movements. Most lifters can probably do one hard deadlift session per week, while two sessions per week might require most lifters to dial down the intensity a bit. A classic recommendations for adapting to a larger workload that you might use for the deadlift is this:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>First increase the frequency.</strong> Go from one deadlift session to two, more or less by splitting your current training volume in two.</li>



<li><strong>Then increase the volume.</strong> Slowly ramp up the volume by adding easy sets, so that you are well on the safe side of doing too much, too soon.</li>



<li><strong>Finally increase the intensity (load).</strong> When you are accustomed to two deadlift sessions per week, you might start to increase the intensity of load you&#8217;re using.</li>
</ol>



<p>A strategy we like, and that we employ in our popular deadlift program <em>Deadlift Disco</em> (which you can find <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">in our app</a>), is to have two deadlift sessions in a week:</p>



<ol>
<li>One session (Monday) with regular deadlifts.</li>



<li>Another session (Friday) with a deadlift variant – in the case of Deadlift Disco, we use <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/pause-deadlift/">paused deadlifts</a>.</li>
</ol>



<p>Typically, the second session is a bit easier than the regular deadlift session and can consist of a variation that aids your competition style. We believe paused deadlifts are a generally helpful variation, but other options might be deficit deadlifts, trap bar deadlifts, or rack pulls.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Load &amp; Reps for the Deadlift</h3>



<p>Your strength can improve from training with both high and low loads, but when you compare them head to head, lifting heavy weights is slightly more effective if you want to get better at, well, lifting heavy weights.</p>



<p>A meta-analysis of 14 studies with mostly untrained participants found that training with more than 60% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>led to significantly higher strength gains than training with 60% or less.<span id='easy-footnote-29-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-29-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28834797&quot;&gt;J Strength Cond Res. 2017 Dec;31(12):3508-3523. doi: 10.1519/JSC.0000000000002200. Strength and Hypertrophy Adaptations Between Low- vs. High-Load Resistance Training: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>29</sup></a></span>



<p>There are several rep and loading strategies that work, as long as you heed the principle of specificity (i.e. lifting heavy every once in a while) and progressive overload (e.g. adding weight or reps).</p>



<p>Without getting into periodization practices, here are three basic templates for structuring your workouts in the context of the two principles mentioned above. Try to increase weights/reps over time.</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Pyramid training.</strong> Increase the weights in a pyramid fashion during your workout. E.g., go from 6–10 reps at 60% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM</a>, up to 1+ reps at 90%, and back down to 60% again. That way, you&#8217;ll get some practice at heavier weights while still getting a good amount of volume in.</li>



<li><strong>Slug away at 80%.</strong> The range of about 75–85% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>is the powerlifters bread and butter. It&#8217;s heavy enough to be specific training for max attempts, but not so heavy that it burns you out. It&#8217;s typically possible to accumulate a large, effective volume at this intensity. Something like 6–10 sets x 2–3 reps might be appropriate.</li>



<li><strong>Heavy plus assistance lifts.</strong> Work up to one max effort set at 85–90% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM</a>, maybe follow up with 1–2 lighter back-off sets, and then fill in with volume from your favorite assistance exercises for <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/leg-muscles-exercises-workout/">legs</a>, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">glutes</a>, and <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/back-muscles-exercises-workout/">back</a>.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Assistance Exercises for the Deadlift</h3>



<p>Assistance exercises can generally be divided in two groups, based on their desired training effect:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Hypertrophy.</strong> Exercises that strengthen and grow the <em>muscles </em>used in the lift.</li>



<li><strong>Strength/Technique.</strong> Exercises that strengthen the <em>movement</em>, or improve the <em>performance or technique</em> of the lift.</li>
</ul>



<p><em>Note: one exercise might fit in both categories.</em></p>



<p>Let&#8217;s explore the two categories and give some examples of appropriate exercises.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Assistance Exercises for Muscles Used in the Deadlift</h3>



<p>The primary movers in the deadlift are the knee extensors (<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/quad-muscles-exercises-workout/">quadriceps</a>), hip extensors (<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">glutes</a>, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hamstring-muscles-exercises-workout/">hamstrings</a>, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hip-adductor-muscles-exercises-workout/">adductors</a>), and back extensors (mostly your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-back-muscles-exercises-workout/">lower back</a>), so that is the muscles you should be most concerned about strengthening and growing.</p>



<p>The options for hypertrophy exercises are many and more a matter of personal preference than anything else. If you can do an exercise with a decent range of motion, get a nice muscle contact, and it doesn&#8217;t hurt – then you can probably use it to <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/build-muscle/">build muscle</a>.</p>



<p>Here is a sample list of exercises that you might use to supplement your training for the muscles involved in the deadlift. If you are hitting <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squats </a>and deadlifts hard, you might only want to pick 1–2 of the exercises below and do 2–3 sets x 1–2 workouts per week. If you deadlift with a low volume (relative to your training level), you can increase the volume of assistance exercises.</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">Squat</a> (if you&#8217;re not already doing them) (knee, hip and back extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bulgarian-split-squat/">Bulgarian split squat</a> (knee and hip extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hip-thrust/">Hip thrust</a> (hip extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/kettlebell-swing/">Kettlebell swing</a> (hip and back extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/back-extension/">Hyperextension</a> (hip and back extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/good-morning/">Good morning</a> (hip and back extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/romanian-deadlift/">Romanian deadlift</a> (hip and back extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/barbell-row/">Barbell row</a> (upper back and isometric training for back and hip extensors)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/farmers-walk/">Farmers walk</a> (core, grip, trapezius, and stability training for hips)</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="variations">Deadlift Variations to Strengthen or Improve Deadlift Technique</h3>



<p>The best exercise to improve your deadlift technique and performance is the deadlift. But, that doesn&#8217;t mean that there are no more tools in the toolbox.</p>



<p>Here are some of the most common deadlift variations that you might use to strengthen your deadlift or improve your technique. They are generally more taxing than the hypertrophy exercises listed earlier and cut in more into your other deadlift volume. Working sets of the exercises listed below should probably be traded in for your regular sets of deadlifts if you&#8217;re already training at a high volume rather than piled on top of it.</p>



<ul>
<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/pause-deadlift/">Pause deadlifts</a>.</strong> Can be used to improve overall technique and strength around the position that you pause in. We generally recommend pausing as close to the floor as possible (just an inch or so above), and for a count of three.</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/deficit-deadlift/">Deficit deadlifts</a>.</strong> Can be used to challenge and strengthen the start in the deadlift, and also might bring about more training for your legs. Do these by standing on a weight plate or some sturdy block, around 1–4 inches high, so that you&#8217;ll have to reach down further to grab and lift the bar.</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/rack-pull/">Rack pulls</a>.</strong> Useful for getting used to heavier weights in your hands, and overloading the later part of a deadlift. Choose rack height at your own discretion, but a common height is to begin with the bar just below your knees.</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/trap-bar-deadlift-with-low-handles/">Trap bar deadlifts</a>.</strong> Distributes the work more evenly between hip and knee extensors, and unloads the back a bit. Can be useful for more balanced development of the lower body, and is a back-friendly substitute.</li>
</ul>



<p>If you identify a need for one of the exercises above, or simply want to introduce more variation in your training, you could try substituting about 30–50% of your deadlifts with one of them. Or, if you are training deadlifts two or more times a week, you might switch out one of the days completely to a variant. In some training blocks when you are far from competition, you might not even have regular deadlifts in your routine at all.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Deadlift Training Programs</h2>



<p>That&#8217;s a lot of information about deadlifting, but how do you convert that into a deadlift training program?</p>



<p>Below follows a few different sample programs for <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/beginner-deadlift-program/">beginner</a>, <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-to-get-stronger-part-2-the-intermediate/">intermediate</a>, and <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-to-get-stronger-part-3-the-advanced/">advanced lifter </a>respectively.</p>



<p>A loose definition of those three might be as follows:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Beginner:</strong> Someone who is new to deadlifting. Can expect to get stronger from workout to workout.</li>



<li><strong>Intermediate:</strong> Someone who has been training deadlifts for about six months (give or take a few months). Can expect to get stronger from week to week.</li>



<li><strong>Advanced:</strong> Someone who has been deadlifting for a year or more. Can expect to get stronger&nbsp;from month to month, or from training block to training block.</li>
</ul>



<p>You can read more about these definitions in: <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-to-get-stronger-part-3-the-advanced/">How to Get Stronger, Part 3: The Advanced</a>.</p>



<p>What separates a beginners training from an advanced lifters?</p>



<p>Primarily two things:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Volume:</strong> To continue bringing about new adaptations from the training (i.e., getting bigger and stronger), you need to increase the stimulus. You will obviously do this in one part by increasing the weights you&#8217;re training with, but the other part is by increasing the total number of sets and reps you do. Throughout the course of your career, your training volume will need to increase.</li>



<li><strong>Specificity:</strong> The earlier in your training career you are, the more general you can afford to be and still make gains. The more advanced you are, the more specific your training will have to be. For the deadlifter striving to increase his <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM</a>, this means that you will increase the amount of training you do at a high intensity (high % of your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM</a>) throughout your lifting career.</li>
</ul>



<p>Lets have a look at the sample programs.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Beginner Deadlift Training Program: 1–2x/week</h3>



<p>A beginner&#8217;s deadlift program can be simple. It can consist of one single workout that you repeat once or twice a week.</p>



<p>Begin your training program at an easy weight, where you are in control of the technique.</p>



<p><strong>Beginner Deadlift Workout:</strong></p>



<ul>
<li> <strong>Deadlift:</strong> 3 sets x 5 reps</li>
</ul>



<p>If you manage to do all 3 sets x 5 reps, increase the weight by 5–10 pounds (2.5–5 kg) for the next workout. If you can&#8217;t do 3 set x 5 reps, keep training with the same weight every workout until you successfully get all reps.</p>



<p>Our <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/barbell-training-program-for-the-beginner/">beginner barbell program</a> is a great program to start with. In that program, you will alternate between <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/squat/">squats </a>and deadlifts each workout, both of which complement each other beautifully.</p>



<p>When you can no longer increase the weight or even by a single rep between workouts, you are ready for intermediate phase training.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Intermediate Deadlift Training Program: 2x/week</h3>



<p>Instead of aiming to make noticeable strength gains every workout, the intermediate lifter will strive to make progress from week to week. Therefore, the lifter will only really push their limit once every week.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-to-get-stronger-part-2-the-intermediate/">The intermediate lifter</a>&nbsp;will likely need slightly more training volume than the beginner lifter, and will also need to train closer to his or her <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>for the best strength gains.</p>



<p>Increased muscle mass will begin to play a greater role for long-term strength gains, and therefore some hypertrophy-focused training is added.</p>



<p>Here&#8217;s an example of an <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/intermediate-deadlift-program/">intermediate deadlift program</a> that consists of one heavy and one light workout per week. The point is to try and increase the weight you are lifting every heavy workout, while the light workouts add training frequency and volume.</p>



<p><strong>Intermediate Deadlift Workout A (Heavy):</strong></p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Deadlift:</strong>&nbsp;3 sets x 3 reps x 80% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>– <em>once you can complete all reps, increase the weight by 5 lbs/2.5 kg for the next workout.</em></li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/romanian-deadlift/">Romanian Deadlift</a>:</strong>&nbsp;3 sets x 8 reps</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/barbell-row/">Barbell Row</a>:</strong>&nbsp;3 sets x 10 reps</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>Intermediate Workout B (Light):</strong></p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Deadlift:</strong> 5 sets x 5 reps – <em>with 80% of the weight used in workout A.</em></li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/front-squat/">Front Squat</a>:</strong> 3 sets x 5 reps</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/barbell-row/">Barbell Row</a>:</strong>&nbsp;3 sets x 10 reps </li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Advanced Deadlift Training Program: 2x/week</h3>



<p><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/how-to-get-stronger-part-3-the-advanced/">The advanced lifter&nbsp;</a>acknowledges that the sweet newbie gains have come and gone, and you will likely only see noticeable strength gains every 1–2 months on average – if you’re even that lucky.&nbsp;<strong><em>Deadlift Disco</em></strong>, the deadlift training program in&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">our app</a>, is 6 weeks long, which we’ve found to be something of a sweet spot for many lifters.</p>



<p>It is harder to give samples of advanced training programs since as lifters progress in their training, they become less homogenous, and the importance of individualization increases. Therefore, we will describe how we’ve designed the progression in Deadlift Disco so that you can use that information to plan your own training. Or, if you’d prefer: download&nbsp;<a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">our app</a>, register for premium, and try the program yourself.</p>



<p>Deadlift Disco is designed so that you can train it continuously for several cycles in a row. You deadlift twice a week: one heavier session with regular deadlifts progressing mainly in intensity (% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM</a>) and one lighter session with <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/pause-deadlift/">pause deadlifts</a>.</p>



<p>The breakdown of the programs progression is this:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>The volume&nbsp;</strong>(in terms of sets of deadlifts) increases over the first few weeks and peaks in weeks 3 and 4, following an inverted U-shape. The final week, containing the max attempt, functions as a taper and also something of a deload before the next cycle.</li>



<li><strong>The peak % of 1RM&nbsp;</strong>climbs from 80% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>in week one, to 102.5% (your new max attempt) in week 6.</li>



<li><strong>The average % of 1RM&nbsp;</strong>increases gradually over the course of the six weeks, from 69% of <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/">1RM </a>in the first few weeks, reaching 79% at most in week 6.</li>
</ul>



<p>Here’s a visual representation:</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="706" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-training-program.png?resize=700%2C706&#038;ssl=1" alt="Deadlift training program" class="wp-image-8645" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-training-program.png?w=826&amp;ssl=1 826w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-training-program.png?resize=297%2C300&amp;ssl=1 297w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-training-program.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Deadlift-training-program.png?resize=768%2C775&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<p><strong>The gist of the program is this:</strong></p>



<ol>
<li>You start off in a somewhat comfortable place, and then increase the volume and your training weights gradually from there, trying to push your limits just enough to stimulate new gains.</li>



<li>You finish the training cycle with a taper and a max attempt in week 6.</li>



<li>If the program seemed productive to you, and you believe you will benefit from another cycle, increase your submitted 1RM and go through another cycle of training.</li>
</ol>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Useful Equipment for Deadlifting</h2>



<p>Let&#8217;s have a look at some of the most useful and important equipment considerations for deadlifting.</p>



<p>We will be covering:</p>



<ul>
<li>Shoes</li>



<li>Chalk</li>



<li>Belt</li>



<li>Lifting straps</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Shoes for Deadlifting</h3>



<p>There are three main things to consider when choosing shoes for deadlifting:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Stability.</strong> You&#8217;ll want a firm or even hard sole, to keep your foot stable while lifting. Avoid soft and wobbly jogging shoes, as their instability will hurt your performance and increase injury risk. For optimal force transfer into the ground (which you need in order to lift the bar), you need good ground contact.</li>



<li><strong>Height.</strong> Remember: the beginning of the deadlift is the hardest part, and the more bent over you are, the weaker you are. The height of the soles will affect how much you have to bend forward, so if your goal is to lift as much weight as possible, it is advantageous to use shoes with thin soles.</li>



<li><strong>Friction.</strong> This is mostly an issue for those of you who pull sumo – with a conventional foot position (feet about under your hips), you&#8217;re not very dependent on friction. For sumo lifters however, that is what will keep your feet from slipping away.</li>
</ol>



<p>It is not a coincidence that many lifters choose to train in their socks or even barefoot, if the gym allows them. It puts them close to the ground, and there is no instability from a soft sole. In competition, the same lifters might use deadlift slippers. Personally, I like deadlifting in minimalistic shoes (sometimes called by the idiotic name &#8220;barefoot shoes&#8221;), and currently use a pair Stealth II from Vivobarefoot. The sole is only 3 mm thick and has great friction.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Chalk</h3>



<p>Chalk is the name of the white stuff you put in your hands (and sometimes on your back when you&#8217;re squatting of benching) to dry them up and inrease the friction, thereby giving you a better grip. Actually, real chalk isn&#8217;t in use any more, as it has been replaced by (most commonly) magnesium carbonate. The name chalk, however, remains.</p>



<p>It&#8217;s effect on your grip is immense, and once you&#8217;re past the beginner phase, you can&#8217;t really train deadlifts properly without either chalk or lifting straps.</p>



<p>And, if you&#8217;ve never tried chalk, your grip might be holding you back without you even knowing it.</p>



<p>I clearly remember when I first got into deadlifting myself. My training weights were about 120 kg for sets of five, when I bought my first block of chalk. Next deadlift workout, with the aid of chalk, I could suddenly add 20 kg to that, and pull 140 kg for fives. Needless to say, such a performance improvement will lead to a vastly better training effect for all the other muscles used in the deadlift. Your grip will still be worked sufficiently from the increased weight, and all other training that you do.</p>



<p>Chalk is probably as close to a must-have for deadlifts as it gets.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Belt for Deadlifting</h3>



<p>A lifting belt is typically between 2 to 4 inches wide, and aids you by increasing the intra-abdominal pressure.<span id='easy-footnote-30-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-30-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2709981&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 1989 Apr;21(2):186-90. Effects of a belt on intra-abdominal pressure during weight lifting.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>30</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-31-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-31-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2304406&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 1990 Feb;22(1):117-26. The effectiveness of weight-belts during the squat exercise.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>31</sup></a></span> This stiffens your core, and helps most people lift about 5–10% more weight – at least after they have been accustomed to wearing a belt, it can be quite uncomfortable in the beginning.</p>



<p>If using a belt enables you to lift more weight, than that will most likely be positive for the training effect in your legs, hips, trapezius and grip. They get to work against a heavier weight, while not getting any direct help from the belt.</p>



<p>But what about your core? A common argument is that a belt will weaken your core muscles by doing the work for them. EMG-studies does not support this argument, as they either find small or no differences in core muscle activation.<span id='easy-footnote-32-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-32-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11932579&quot;&gt;Med Sci Sports Exerc. 2002 Apr;34(4):682-8. An electromyographic analysis of sumo and conventional style deadlifts.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>32</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-33-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-33-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Abstract/1999/11000/The_Use_of_Lumbar_Supporting_Weight_Belts_While.14.aspx&quot;&gt;J Strength Cond Res. 1999 Nov.&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Abstract/1999/11000/The_Use_of_Lumbar_Supporting_Weight_Belts_While.14.aspx&quot;&gt;The Use of Lumbar-Supporting Weight Belts While Performing Squats: Erector Spinae Electromyographic Activity.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>33</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-34-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-34-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11710410&quot;&gt;J Strength Cond Res. 2001 May;15(2):235-40. The effects of a weight belt on trunk and leg muscle activity and joint kinematics during the squat exercise.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>34</sup></a></span> <span id='easy-footnote-35-8652' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-35-8652' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10619094&quot;&gt;Clin Biomech (Bristol, Avon). 1999 Feb;14(2):79-87. Effects of abdominal belts on intra-abdominal pressure, intra-muscular pressure in the erector spinae muscles and myoelectrical activities of trunk muscles.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>35</sup></a></span> </p>



<p>The belt probably changes the muscle activation pattern in some ways, however, and it might be a good idea to train both with and without a belt, so that you practice both activation patterns.</p>



<p>We recommend that you use a belt if you compete in powerlifting or a similar sport where you can use a belt in competition (given that it actually improves your performance, of course). You might also want to use a belt if you are a bodybuilder or train for general strength and hypertrophy, as the belt will likely give your muscles a better training stimulus.</p>



<p>If you don&#8217;t train to compete in powerlifting or other sports where deadlifts with a belt is a common event, then it probably doesn&#8217;t matter too much if you use a belt or not in your training. On the one hand the belt might enable your legs and hips a better training stimulus, but on the other hand you might want to practice bracing your core without a belt if you&#8217;re going to use your strength without a belt. The answer might lie somewhere in between, and you might be best off using a belt periodically, or only for some of your sets.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Lifting Straps in the Deadlift</h3>



<p>Lifting straps aids your grip by securing your hands to the bar. This comes with both pros and cons, and you can read more about them in the <a href="#liftingstraps">grip section</a>.</p>



<p>While you probably shouldn&#8217;t use lifting straps all the time, they can still be a valuable tool in your gym bag.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Frequently Asked Questions</h2>



<p>Here are some answers to frequently asked questions about deadlifting. Can&#8217;t find the answer to your question? Leave a comment, and we&#8217;ll try to answer!</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Are Deadlifts Dangerous?</h3>



<p>&#8220;The dose makes the poison&#8221;. </p>



<p>Deadlifts are not inherently dangerous – in fact, they have even been used to <em>treat</em> back pain successfully in patients with back pain, like in <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25641309">this study</a>.</p>



<p>Deadlifts strengthen and stress your body, and the most important things you can do to ensure the safety of deadlifting is to:</p>



<ol>
<li><strong>Learn proper deadlift form. </strong>As laid out earlier in this guide.</li>



<li><strong>Gradually increase load and training volume.</strong> To give your body time to adapt.</li>
</ol>



<p>If you do these two things, you are likely to get the reward that everyone covets from deadlifting: a healthy, strong and resilient back.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Will Deadlifts Make Your Waist Bigger?</h3>



<p>Many people use strength training not only to perform and feel better about themselves, but also to look better. One coveted feature of appearance is a slim waist, maybe coupled with broad shoulders and powerful glutes. How does deadlifts fit into this? And will they make your waist bigger?</p>



<p>Let&#8217;s look at the muscles mainly worked by deadlifts:</p>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/lower-back-muscles-exercises-workout/">Lower back</a> (erector spinae)</li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/glute-muscles-exercises-workout/">Glutes</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/quad-muscles-exercises-workout/">Quads</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hamstring-muscles-exercises-workout/">Hamstrings</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/hip-adductor-muscles-exercises-workout/">Adductors</a></li>



<li><span style="font-size: inherit; background-color: initial;"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/trapezius-muscle-exercises-workout/">Trapezius</a></span></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/forearm-flexors-and-grip-muscles-exercises-workout/">Grip muscles</a></li>
</ul>



<p>None of these muscles will make your waist bigger. On the contrary, the development of these muscles will enhance your athletic appearance, and make you look better both with and without clothes on.</p>



<p>It is first when we look at the stabilizing <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/core-muscles-exercises-workout/">core muscles</a> used in the deadlifts that we find the source of these worries. These muscles are mainly your transversus abdominis and your <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/obliques-muscles-exercises-workout/">obliques</a>.</p>



<p>The transversus abdominis and obliques (internal and external) are three of your abdominal muscles and run between your pelvis, ribs, and the fascia of your back.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="499" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Abdominal-muscles.jpg?resize=700%2C499&#038;ssl=1" alt="Abdominal muscles" class="wp-image-658" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Abdominal-muscles.jpg?w=967&amp;ssl=1 967w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Abdominal-muscles.jpg?resize=300%2C214&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Abdominal-muscles.jpg?resize=768%2C548&amp;ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Transversus abdominis (left) and external obliques (right). Both are worked to some extent by deadlifts.</figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Now, the problem with this line of thinking is two-fold:</p>



<ol>
<li>Deadlifts are not that good of an exercise to train these muscles to begin with. They are worked to some extent from it, but there are better options.</li>



<li>If these muscles are well developed, they will contribute to your appearance and look good!</li>
</ol>



<p>I&#8217;ve yet to come across a single deadlifter that dieted down to low body fat and was displeased by how their abs look. Rather they find that their abs have developed quite nicely.</p>



<p>Do not avoid deadlifts on the premise that they make your waist big. It is an unwarranted concern. Rather, deadlifts can be a key exercise in your training regimen to build a better-looking body.</p>



<p>Fat makes your waist big, not deadlifts.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Should You Deadlift With a Dead Start or &#8220;Bounce&#8221;?</h3>



<p>When you&#8217;re putting down the bar to the floor after a deadlift, and you&#8217;re going to perform multiple reps, you have a choice:</p>



<ul>
<li><strong>Dead start.</strong> You can either set the bar down until it is completely still, and start your next rep from a dead start.</li>



<li><strong>Bounce / Touch and Go.</strong> Or you can immediately reverse the movement into another lifts concentric phase. This can be more or less exaggerated, but however you do it, you will still make some use of the kinetic energy of the &#8220;bounce&#8221;, no matter how small it is.</li>
</ul>



<p>First off: definitions. There aint no two ways about the fact that a true deadlift is performed from a <em>dead start</em>. That&#8217;s why it&#8217;s called a dead lift.</p>



<p>However, that doesn&#8217;t mean that you&#8217;re not free to train however you see fit. Let&#8217;s look at the effects of the two styles:</p>



<p><strong>Deadlifting with a dead start &#8230;</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>won&#8217;t let you complete as many reps in a set, or with as heavy a weight.</li>



<li>resembles a single lift the most.</li>



<li>gives you more practice on the hardest part of a deadlift.</li>



<li>improves your opportunity to pull each rep the same way.</li>
</ul>



<p><strong>Deadlifting with touch and go &#8230;</strong></p>



<ul>
<li>will let you complete more reps in a set, or use a heavier weight. This happens due to 1) kinetic energy from the bounce, and 2) the stretch shortening cycle in the muscles (e.g. kinetic energy stored in tendons).</li>



<li>increases the metabolic stress in your muscles, as they will be constantly contracted and thus hindering the blood flow.</li>



<li>partially eliminates the hardest part of a deadlift.</li>



<li>makes it more difficult to pull each rep the same way.</li>
</ul>



<p>Our general recommendation is that you always deadlift with a dead start, but let&#8217;s break it down a bit based on the two training goals <em>strength</em> and <em>hypertrophy</em>.</p>



<p><strong>If you are deadlifting to increase your deadlift </strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/1rm-calculator/"><strong>1RM</strong> </a>then your should most likely do most if not all of your deadlift training with dead starts. That will give you the best practice of the hardest part of the lift, and your muscles fibres will have to do all the work to get the bar moving. If you reverse the lift immediately like with touch and go, the kinetic energy stored in your tendons will take away some of the work that your muscles would otherwise have to do.</p>



<p><strong>If you are deadlifting to build bigger muscles</strong> then it probably matters a whole lot less which style you use. The possibly higher metabolic stress of constantly contracted muscles might be a boon, but on the other hand: nothing will hurt your gains more than an injury, one of which you probably take a greater risk of sustaining with the more uncontrolled technique of touch and go.</p>



<p>So, therefore our general recommendation is: always deadlift with a dead start.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Will Deadlifting With a Mixed Grip Give You an Asymmetrical Back?</h3>



<p>A mixed deadlift grip means that you grab the bar with one hand <em>pronated</em> (palm facing you) and one hand supinated (palm facing away).</p>



<p>The question is: will the supinated hand lead to differences further up in the chain? For example by rotating your upper arm outwards, and maybe even rotating your scapula?</p>



<p>Different lifters have different mobility in their elbow joint, and some might be able to supinate their hand without rotating their upper arm. We feel that most lifters however will rotate their upper arm to some extent, which will translate to slightly different muscle lengths in your upper back. The question is, does it make any real difference?</p>



<p>The muscles in your upper back are not among the muscles primarily worked in the deadlift, meaning that whatever stimulus they receive is pretty low compared to how the glutes, hamstrings and lower back is worked by deadlifting. That is one case against asymmetries developing from deadlifting with a mixed grip.</p>



<p>Another case against it is <em>dilution</em>. Likely, you do more back training than only deadlifts (and if don&#8217;t then maybe you should). If you do rows or pull-ups which directly train your upper back, and where your arm position is symmetrical, that likely has such a large impact on your upper back development that the influence of any asymmetric stimuli from deadlifts is negligible.</p>



<p>A compromise could be that you use mixed grip in about half of your deadlift training, and lifting straps (with a symmetrical, overhand grip) in the other half. Another compromise would be to switch up your mixed grip between sets, but I&#8217;ve personally never really liked that. </p>



<p>Even if you would do 100% of your deadlifts with the same mixed grip, I still think you&#8217;ll be fine.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Why Do I Get Back Pain From Deadlifts?</h3>



<p>Back pain can have a lot of different sources, but if you get them during or after deadlifts, then there are two possibilites that are more likely than others:</p>



<ol>
<li>You are lifting with a technique that gives you pain.</li>



<li>You are lifting more than your back can take (either in terms of weight on the bar, or total training volume).</li>
</ol>



<p>For the technique issue: review the technique outlined above. Specifically, consider your back position and your bracing. Do you round your back when deadlifting? Could you try to lift with a more neutral back, and does it still hurt then? Do you brace your core properly, and could you experiment with different bracing patterns? Could you possibly use your legs more in the lift, and your back less? Those are some technical considerations you might experiment with, to see if anything helps. Get help from a friend or trainer that knows how to deadlift, or film yourself with your phone during sets to review your deadlift technique.</p>



<p>Of course, no technique in the world will help you if you train far more than your back is ready for. You must always gradually adapt to higher training loads, and swift increases in training are a common source of injury. Try decreasing your deadlift volume to 30–50% for a few weeks, and see if it helps. If excessive training was the culprit, that deload might be enough to allow your back to recover.</p>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity"/>



<p><strong>That’s it!</strong>&nbsp;You’ve reached the end of our deadlift guide.</p>



<p>If you’d like to read more articles of this kind on anything related to strength training, be sure to sign up for our free newsletter below, to be notified of new posts!</p>

<article id="post-2397" class="post-2397 page type-page status-publish mv-content-wrapper" itemtype="https://schema.org/CreativeWork" itemscope>
	<div class="inside-article">
		
			<header class="entry-header">
				<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">How to Do Dumbbell Chest Fly: Muscles Worked &#038; Proper Form</h1>			</header>

			
		<div class="entry-content" itemprop="text">
			<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Dumbbell-Chest-Fly.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Dumbbell Chest Fly exercise technique" class="wp-image-2398" data-recalc-dims="1"/></figure></div>


<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-1 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-muscles-worked-in-dumbbell-chest-flyes">Muscles Worked in Dumbbell Chest Flyes</h2>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes-2.png?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscles worked in dumbbell chest flyes" class="wp-image-24032" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes-2.png?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes-2.png?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes-2.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes-2.png?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes-2.png?w=1126&amp;ssl=1 1126w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure></div>


<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-primary-muscles-worked">Primary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-muscles-exercises-workout/">Chest</a></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-secondary-muscles-worked">Secondary muscles worked:</h3>



<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/front-delts-muscle-exercises-workout/">Front Deltoid</a></li>
</ul>
</div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-how-to-do-dumbbell-chest-flyes">How to Do Dumbbell Chest Flyes</h2>



<ol>
<li>Lie on a bench, and lift a pair of dumbbells up to the starting position.</li>



<li>With almost completely straight arms, lower the dumbbells out to your sides.</li>



<li>When you&#8217;ve lowered the dumbbells as deep as possible, reverse the motion and return the dumbbells to the starting position.</li>



<li>Repeat for reps.</li>
</ol>



<p><em>Text and graphics from the <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">StrengthLog </a>app.</em></p>
</div>
</div>



<div id="ez-toc-container" class="ez-toc-v2_0_67_1 counter-hierarchy ez-toc-counter ez-toc-grey ez-toc-container-direction">

Technique">Dumbbell Chest Fly: Proper Form &amp; Technique</a></li><li class='ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2'><a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-4" href="#Common_Mistakes_in_the_Dumbbell_Chest_Fly" title="Common Mistakes in the Dumbbell Chest Fly">Common Mistakes in the Dumbbell Chest Fly</a></li><li class='ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2'><a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-5" href="#Dumbbell_Chest_Fly_Variations" title="Dumbbell Chest Fly Variations">Dumbbell Chest Fly Variations</a></li><li class='ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2'><a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-6" href="#Workouts_and_Training_Programs_That_Include_the_Dumbbell_Chest_Fly" title="Workouts and Training Programs That Include the Dumbbell Chest Fly">Workouts and Training Programs That Include the Dumbbell Chest Fly</a></li><li class='ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2'><a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-7" href="#References" title="References">References</a></li></ul></nav></div>
<h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-which-muscles-do-the-dumbbell-chest-fly-work"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Which_Muscles_Do_the_Dumbbell_Chest_Fly_Work"></span>Which Muscles Do the Dumbbell Chest Fly Work?<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>The dumbbell chest fly is an isolation exercise for your chest muscles and front deltoids.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes.png?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Muscles worked in dumbbell chest flyes" class="wp-image-24034" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes.png?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes.png?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes.png?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Muscles-worked-by-dumbbell-chest-flyes.png?w=1126&amp;ssl=1 1126w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></figure>



<p>As you lower the dumbbells in the chest fly, the load on these muscles increases as they become more stretched, which is beneficial for muscle growth.<span id='easy-footnote-1-2397' class='easy-footnote-margin-adjust'></span><span class='easy-footnote'><a href='#easy-footnote-bottom-1-2397' title='&lt;a href=&quot;https://journals.lww.com/nsca-jscr/Citation/2023/05000/Which_ROMs_Lead_to_Rome__A_Systematic_Review_of.23.aspx&quot;&gt;Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research 37(5):p 1135-1144, May 2023. Which ROMs Lead to Rome? A Systematic Review of the Effects of Range of Motion on Muscle Hypertrophy.&lt;/a&gt;'><sup>1</sup></a></span>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Benefits_of_the_Dumbbell_Chest_Flyes"></span>Benefits of the Dumbbell Chest Flyes<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<ul>
<li><strong>Bigger and stronger pecs.</strong> The dumbbell chest fly is a great exercise for building bigger and stronger pecs.</li>



<li><strong>Accessibility.</strong> All you need to perform dumbbell chest flyes is a bench and a pair of dumbbells, making this exercise very accessible, even for <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/home-chest-workout/">home chest workouts</a>.</li>



<li><strong>Shoulder stability.</strong> Using dumbbells will challenge your shoulders&#8217; stabilizing musculature.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Dumbbell_Chest_Fly_Proper_Form_Technique"></span>Dumbbell Chest Fly: Proper Form &amp; Technique<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<div class="wp-block-columns is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-2 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">
<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow"><div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="695" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?resize=700%2C695&#038;ssl=1" alt="Dumbbell chest flyes starting position" class="wp-image-24048" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?resize=1024%2C1017&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?resize=300%2C298&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?resize=768%2C763&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?resize=1536%2C1525&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?w=1712&amp;ssl=1 1712w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-start.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Starting position</figcaption></figure></div></div>



<div class="wp-block-column is-layout-flow wp-block-column-is-layout-flow"><div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="700" height="700" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end-1024x1024.png?resize=700%2C700&#038;ssl=1" alt="Dumbbell chest flyes starting position" class="wp-image-24049" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?resize=1024%2C1024&amp;ssl=1 1024w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?resize=300%2C300&amp;ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?resize=150%2C150&amp;ssl=1 150w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?resize=768%2C768&amp;ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?resize=1536%2C1536&amp;ssl=1 1536w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?w=1700&amp;ssl=1 1700w, https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/dumbbell-chest-flyes-end.png?w=1400&amp;ssl=1 1400w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" data-recalc-dims="1" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Bottom position</figcaption></figure></div></div>
</div>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Positioning</h3>



<p>Lie flat on a bench, and make sure to keep your whole feet on the ground to maintain balance. Tuck your shoulder blades and keep your chest up to create a stable position. </p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-movement">Movement</h3>



<p>Keep your elbows slightly bent, and hold them in the same position during the entire movement. You want the movement to be in your shoulder joint, by contracting your chest muscles, not in the elbow. Keep both elbows and wrists in the same position during the entire movement.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Common_Mistakes_in_the_Dumbbell_Chest_Fly"></span>Common Mistakes in the Dumbbell Chest Fly<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<ul>
<li><strong>Adding too much weight. </strong>The dumbbell chest fly is an exercise that gets heavy fast in the bottom position, and using heavier weights than you can handle puts you at risk of injury or a breakdown in form, reducing the exercise&#8217;s effectiveness. Start with very light weights and build from there.</li>



<li><strong>Bending your arms. </strong>Keep your arms almost straight to avoid turning the chest fly into a chest press. This will require you to use light weights.</li>
</ul>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Dumbbell_Chest_Fly_Variations"></span>Dumbbell Chest Fly Variations<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<ol>
<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-cable-chest-fly/">Standing Cable Chest Fly</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-resistance-band-chest-fly/">Standing Resistance Band Chest Fly</a></li>
</ol>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-1-standing-cable-chest-fly">1. Standing Cable Chest Fly</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-cable-chest-fly/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/cable-chest-fly.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Standing cable chest fly exercise" class="wp-image-2470" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-cable-chest-fly/">Standing Cable Chest Fly</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>Compared to the dumbbell chest fly, the resistance curve in cable flyes is more evenly distributed. This means your chest muscles get a longer time under tension in each repetition, and you can probably get a better chest pump with this exercise.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">2. Standing Resistance Band Chest Fly</h3>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-resistance-band-chest-fly/"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="600" height="600" src="https://i0.wp.com/www.strengthlog.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/standing-resistance-band-chest-fly.gif?resize=600%2C600&#038;ssl=1" alt="Standing Resistance Band Chest Fly" class="wp-image-19730" data-recalc-dims="1"/></a><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/standing-resistance-band-chest-fly/">Standing Resistance Band Chest Fly</a></figcaption></figure></div>


<p>If you don’t have access to dumbbells or a cable machine, you can perform chest flyes with a resistance band. Attach the band at chest height and work one side at a time. The constant tension in the movement is similar to the cable version. The downside is that it’s harder to adjust the resistance with the banded version.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Workouts_and_Training_Programs_That_Include_the_Dumbbell_Chest_Fly"></span>Workouts and Training Programs That Include the Dumbbell Chest Fly<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<ul>
<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/advanced-bench-press-program/">Advanced Bench Press Program</a>. 3x/week.</strong>&nbsp;A nine-week long bench press program for the advanced lifter, who needs to do a lot of training in order to progress. </li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/bodybuilding-ballet/">Bodybuilding Ballet</a>. 4–6x/week.</strong>&nbsp;An advanced bodybuilding program and one of the most popular programs in our app.</li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-and-shoulder-workout/">Chest and Shoulder Workout Routine</a>.</strong></li>



<li><strong><a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/chest-shoulder-and-tricep-workout/">Chest, Shoulder, and Tricep Bodybuilding Workout</a>.</strong></li>
</ul>



<p>All these workouts and training programs are available in our <a href="https://www.strengthlog.com/">free workout log app</a> StrengthLog.</p>
